item.name: 1960: The Making of the President
item.comment: This definitely takes more plays to get your head around, the rules are not that complex, despite a few special rules when it comes to intriciate details such as the canditates location etc., but the strategy, especially long-term is where the crux lies in this game. Knowing where to invest your campaign points and in the media etc. and accepting defeat in some states while going for a surprise attack in another is what makes this game interesting. I know it is based on the actual election mechanism but the fact that some states are worth ten times the votes than others feels really weird. HX

item.name: 20th Century
item.comment: Again, I like the basic premise of the game and the (attempted) mixture of Carcassonne and run-of-the-mill Euro/Economic game. But why give each player his 'own' little country to develop instead of maximizing interaction by (as in Carcassonne) have players build and compete in the same country, helping each other involuntarily, profiting of each other, collaborating in times of need etc., make it less solitaire. The artwork is average but it very well balanced and polished. So, above average Euro which could have been better.

item.name: 221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
item.comment:
As a sherlockian, I do enjoy this game for its theme and appeal. The "case" system is nice and makes this game quite replayable (until you solved the cases that is) and works better than Cluedo which relies on the randomizer. The game mechanics are as good as non-existens. You have to roll the dice and walk around the board. There are not a lot of other elements in the game, so what i comes down to is reading clues and solving the case. It can be a bit tedious, because there is only one die, and sometimes a few rounds consist of people rolling for the dice and nothing happens. Some of the clues are a bit difficult for younger people or non-English citizens as they refer to Literature, History, Poetry etc. I found that a bit frustrating, because should you not happen to know the answer, you have no chance of solving the case by means of deduction and logic.
Other than that, a fun game and my girlfriend enjoys it.
Neat little card game, whose strategic implications become clearer after a few plays. The ability to force other people to play (as in not allowing the to pass) really makes this a nasty game.

item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: A fun light card game with a bit of tactics and lots of luck, makes more fun the more players are involved.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: A nice variant of efficiency engine games with a bit more possible interaction due to trading, military and victory points based on opponents' buildings. I especially like the mechanic of choosing one card from your hand and passing on the remaining cards. It plays very quick and I the only thing that is left for me to find out is whether it plays well with 2 players.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment: Definitely changes the scope and feel of the original 7 Wonders, if only because the game becomes less random and more reliant on a pre-planned (as in leader choice) strategy. It might repel the family and casual gamers but add some needed depth for strategist. I do like it a lot.

item.name: Acqua Dolce
item.comment: An neat little card with lovely graphics, if you like fish that is. I felt that there is not much strategy too it and almost the whole game depends on card draws, with some level of deciding when to hold back some cards etc. It is definitely not a card game that is as ingenious as others I have played but still fairly enjoyable.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: My dad and his friends play this regulary and I have been playing it with them for quiet some time. It is a very abstract game and I am very much a fan of heavily themed games. The game mechanics are simple but work well. The fact that other people see what "stocks" you buy is the crux of the game, because it is around the stock buying the bluffing and speculation evolves. Think Scrabble with waging. I do prefer the older editions over the new ones. My Dad has the 3M Bookshelf edition and the packaging is fantastic.

item.name: After Pablo
item.comment:
Fantastic theme. Although I am sure when this is getting republished (if !) then the theme will probably be changed into something more family friendly. There are many paths to victory and the game is very intuitively designed despite its complexity which is a sign of a great game design.
EDIT: Played it twice now and I do have a sneak suspicion that there might be a bit of a runaway leader problem here. Maybe it were only my plays that turned out that way but I will have to look out for that.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment:
Considering that you are playing in a time of exploration, this game is very linear and dry. I do like the basic flow of the game and the various characters and abilities make for simple, yet nice tactical decisions, but why not make the 'new world' more random, luck-based and exciting, sort of mix up the dry Euromechanics with some real discovering. The designers went for the save route but for the sake of more excitement in my opinion. For a Eurogame, this has amazing pieces and that definitely notched up the rating a little bit.
EDIT: After a few plays, I think the game is not flexible enough despite random buildings and goods, the game plays very similar each time, especially with experienced players who decide on one strategy and keep going for it for the whole game.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment: I have played this only once and with the Ireland expansion, so my insight into Age of Steam is rather limited. I do like the game however. It is a solid game. I must say I would have preferred more theme and artwork, I am not a Eurogamer after all. Furthermore, the leading player has an advantate due to the accumulative success. Once in the lead stays in the lead. We played a three player game and one player was doomed from the 4th turn whence he could not recover, as he was tied up in cost and could not build etc. There should have been some sort of houserule which helps the last player back to his feet (the last player cannot "lose" income" or so). A nice game which is a tad to dry for my taste, but I am happy to play it again. HX

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: I am not a big fan, in fact I do not like "efficiency engine" games. Slowly build up a proficient farm and so forth is just not my cup of tea. I prefer limited options (not due the lack of family counters but lack of options in general) and more luck, luck, luck. Random events, dice, and so forth. Without random elements, it is not a game, it is a puzzle, a calculation exercise, pure stress, no fun. If I want to do something that requires a lot of energy and results in something very efficient, I go to work or take a math exam. So, Agricola is not my type of game. No surprise there, seeing that I do not like Dungeon Lords, Dominion and RFTG for the same reason. I have not played with the interactive deck, so I cannot comment on that but Agricola felt like a multi-solitaire game to me, everybody is building his own little farm and there is some interaction (choice of action) but that is it. Not my cuppa.HX

item.name: Alcatraz: The Scapegoat
item.comment: A very interesting traitor/scapegoat boardgame. I like the voting mechanic and the general flow of the game. I think this is a sleeper hit for sure.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment:
A very 'simple' but not uninteresting game tile / card collection. There is not as much interaction as I would prefer and it is pretty much up to each individual player to make his fortune in this game with the actions of the other players' only indirectly influence your own. It is still nice to see when your opponents gnarl their teeth when you snatch away the card or tile away from them but I would not say that this game is very interactive or competitive in the sense of being confrontational. But it makes it the better family game where everyone can peacefully build and tend to his own city, keeping an eye out for what the others are doing without engaging in any sort of all-out bidding wars.
EDIT: Does not scale with more players at all. We played a six-player game and it fell really flat.

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: Alien frontiers took the Kingsburg mechanics and propelled it into space. Alas, in my experience, making the players use all their dice at once (instead of taking turns as in Kingsburg) generates way too much downtime and AP. That being said, I do prefer Kingsburg.

item.name: Alles Käse!
item.comment: Very light and random filler game. You can play it safe, but it sure is less fun. There is only one strategy that applies to all players in all situation, so in the end, it all comes down to luck mostly. It still can be fun, but don't try this with euro- or heavygamers.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: One of Kmizia's heavier games (a la Tigris & Euphrates) and once again, the theme is some random ancient civilization. In this case, it works very well because you are building pyramids and the game even plays in two epochs, the old and new kingdom, Egypt here we come ! The game can be very brainburning, especially for first-timers (like I was) because the scoring only takes place in 2 out of 6 rounds and as such, your actions and strategies build up to those phases instead of going for the quick points all the time. I love the auction mechanic that this game uses (the same as in 20th Century). There could be a tad more interaction in later phases, but what the heck, great stuff.

item.name: Angkor
item.comment: You get what you expect in this game. A light theme, quite playful and big plastic pieces which make it look more than a kids' game than it actually is. There is some luck in the game, which can be countered by a good strategy but some people might not like the amount of luck here. The game is pretty much all about having two actions when you need three. I like it.

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Wow, what an incredibly fun game. So silly and yet so thrilling, that very moment when everything falls apart and you have to start again. I love this game.

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Addictive little dexteritiy game that is always good for lots of laughs and shaking fists. Good for kids and adults alike

item.name: Anno Domini: Erfindungen
item.comment: Great Twist on general trivia game and very enjoyable that like a good banter and discussion and have a general interest in fun trivia and history (or inventions that is). The mechanics are bit unpolished, especially the winning conditions, then again, that is not what this game is about, better keep it simple. Lovely stuff.

item.name: Anno Domini: VIP
item.comment: Not the best edition of an otherwise fine game. Less interesting and a tad harder than most of the other ones

item.name: Archaeology: The Card Game
item.comment: A nice card game that resembles many similar two player card games, like Jambo or Jaipur, players collect sets by interacting with a market on the table, partially exchanging items and relying on luck and push-your-luck to complete sets to get an exponential number of points. Good game.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
My favourite Boardgame. I have been playing it solitaire mostly and with others a few times. The theme is amazing (Lovecraft Ho!) and the game mechanics too. There is a lot of random stuff going on, which ties in nicely with the chaotic theme of the Cthulhu mythos, although I know a lot of Eurogamers who would not enjoy this. The expansion packs turn this into a huge game and it can easily compete with Descent in terms of scope. Only drawback, if you play with more than four players it gets a bit too long and confusing. Also, if you are not in the right mood, play with the wrong people or in the wrong place, all the "flavour" of the game might not come through.
EDIT: I have played this twice with groups who did not enjoy it or found the experience boring, and it dragged my experience and joy down with it and I have to say, this game is a definite 10 for me IN THEORY. When played with the wrong group, this can be one of the worst games ever.

item.name: Ascending Empires
item.comment: I had a bad feeling about this from the moment I laid eyes on it. Dexterity and Space 4X ? Sadly, I was right, at least in my opinion. The marriage between flicking and building a space empire does not work and the two mechanics don't create the promised hybrid. I feel that the core game, apart from the flicking is really not that interesting a quite stagnant and dry. The flicking itself is kept at bay when it comes to the welcome insanity of outrageous attempts because usually, you will just go from planet to planet and flick very cautiously. But what the hell is the flicking about if not for shooting your stuff all over the place ? Also, the game takes too long, we played this for almost three hours and did not finish it, mostly because we ran out of time, but I also ran out of fun to be honest. The problem is that this game might be a novelty mix but it is neither a good dexterity game nor a good Euro game and I would rather play a better dexterity game or a better Euro game than attempting to squeeze it all into on play. This game could have been a winner, if only the playing were shorter. The board does not sit flat either, which is real shame, considering you need to flick your way through space. Disappointing.

item.name: Atlas & Zeus
item.comment:
Boy, was I surprised when I played this the first time. It looks ugly as a troll baby but the game hidden in this gem is delightful, very simple but lots of tactical subtleties and also backstabbing, a bit of randomness and reading your opponent like a book, that is, you should at least try. The artwork on the tiles is much better than the artwork on the box which is horrid, I do not know what went wrong there. The cards are a bit smallish and not nice to handle but it is a transportable 2-player game after all, so I can see why they went for that. A great 2-player game with a nice pace and which also becomes increasingly more complex as you play, due to the scarcity of survivors and the resulting vulnerability of each player.
A very good 2-player game !

item.name: AtmosFear: Khufu – The Mummy
item.comment: I never liked DVD games, because the reason I play boardgame is because they are no DVDs or Computers involved. The game is pretty much catered for Children, goofy videos and colourful pieces. The basic game evolves around simple waging and dice rolling. The artwork is not very good. The novelty of the DVD quickly wears of and keep interrupting the play of the game. I do not like the game and would not recommend it.
item.wishlistcomment: Bought this game new from Woolworths. All parts are complete and in excellent condition, except for one 'coin' which I replaced with an other one.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: To me, Attika is another good example of throwing lots and lots of mechanics into one big pile and making a game out of it that might work in terms of mechanics but is not more than the sum of its parts and I fail to see the overarching concept and ingenious 'designer's handwriting' behind the run-of-the-mill euro mechanics. The basic idea is not bad and almost sounds like a simplified checkers or chess version, a competitive abstract game but it is muddled up some inelegant rules and possible actions which prevents the game to flow and instead every turn feels like a damp squib. I am sure some people will like this game, but it did not hit a nerve with me.

item.name: Avalanche
item.comment: Used to play this as a kid and enjoyed it very much due to the chaos that can be caused when the marbles rumble all over the place. As a game it is rather simple and might not be of much interest of adults.

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment:
Good racing game with a very nice theme. The mechanics are simple, yet effective and this is one of the few games which works smoothly and quick with 5 or more people. Good for families
EDIT: I have played the new edition and can NOT recommend it. The chance of running out of cards has been decreased and where is the fun in that ? The board looks better but is also harder to make out. Also, there are less tracks available.

item.name: Back to the Future: The Card Game
item.comment: As much as I like the Back to the Future movies, this card game is not much fun. Yes, it may be based on a great license but the novelty quickly wears off, given that there are only two sides to every "card". Thus, Emmet Brown is either dead or alive. The idea of changing the course of history in order to make sure you are still alive in the future is a great one and would make for a great game but this is not it. It is very random and that makes fun if not taken seriously, but any form of strategy you might have is redundant.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment: Backgammon is not my cup of tea, I found it to dry and people who play it regulary play it so fast and often that it kind of takes away what I like in boardgames, the tranquility and focus. Too rapid for me and too abstract. I do prefer Chess.

item.name: Balance Duels
item.comment: A very interesting 'toy' that does feel like a game. Good concept but looks a bit ugly. I am just worried that the game is too easy to solve and does not offers as much replayability and depth as other abstract games (go / chess etc.)

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: Maybe I should have played this with more than 4 players, but if the box says 4 players or up, I assume it works with that number and is not "really the same game" (quote). I found this boring and dull, more like a random trick taking game, almost zero strategy and way too much luck for a game that simple. Not my cup of tea. I much prefer the similar Cash N Guns. HX

item.name: Barbarossa und die Rätselmeister
item.comment: At first sight, the scoring system and rules seem way too fiddly for what this game actually tries to be. A guessing game a la 20 questions (Yes/No answers) and the clues are models made of plasticine. Way before Dixit, this game forces the players to create their models in a way that they give away enough to be guessed but not too early or too late. Some people will be annoyed by the clunky way this game goes about its business and also the roll-and-move portion of the game which can win you the game if you're lucky. I think this game is okay, but all the mechanics and tweaks don't change the fact that this game is pretty much a light 20-Questions clone and if that is something you don't enjoy, this game won't change your mind. I think there are better and more interesting party games out there, so I will probably trade this away.

item.name: Barrel of Monkeys
item.comment: Played this once and did not get it. I found it fun to play around with the pieces but as a game, I found it way too simple and uninspiring.

item.name: The Battle for Hill 218
item.comment: An interesting confrontational puzzle game where you have to come up with the most efficient card-combos sooner than your opponent. I am not sure how replayable this is, given that some combos are more lethal than others, but I do like this. A shame it's only two player, will see less play than it ought to.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: A typical Knizia game that reminds me of Lost Cities but this one is much harder and even a tad vicious. Keeping an overview over all the cards that have been played both by yourself and the opponent can be quiet the drill. It takes a few plays to become fluid in this game, but then it is a very dense and focused two-player skirmish. I do like it, not keen on the 'theme' or the artwork but it is a Knizia so that is what I had to expect really.

item.name: Battle Masters
item.comment: I used to play this for hours in my parent's house when I was a kid. Instead of game board there is a game map, which unfolds into a landscape on which the battles take place. By now, I realize Battle Masters is pretty much the most toned down version of miniature wargaming you can find, but it is good for young kids or people who prefer a simpler and more in-your-face approach to war gaming.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
This is the first semi-cooperative game I played and I enjoyed it very much. Great mechanics and lots of variety in possible strategies, both for the good and evil players. There are a few reasons why this is not a 10 to me. 1: The Theme, I am not a Sci-Fi fan and never saw a single BG episode, so it does not add or take anything for me. If anything, it makes the game harder to relate to. 2: The game encourages social gaming, a lot ! So if you are playing with people who are not into that, the game loses lots of its appeal. Also, the is a lot of accusing, nastyness and betrayal going on, which can be fun, but some people may not like that sort of interaction. 3.) Experienced players have an advantage over newbies. Other than that, Amazing game.#
EDIT: I would rathe this a 10 for the game that takes place before the Cylon(s) is revealed, it becomes less exciting and rather anticlimactic afterwards.
EDIT: Played Shadows over Camelot for the first 2 times today and must say that it is the superior 'traitor' game, not by much but still. I prefer the theme, playing time and nature of the climax.

item.name: Bazaar
item.comment: Simple yet effective and very nicely designed. Many of today's Eurogames could learn from this, stop looking so terribly dull, the war is over for god's sake. Anyway, Bazaar is fun and played it loads with my Dad. It is a good gateway game for children because it does not deal with stocks, bonds or war but can be quite hard to master, yet simple to pick up.

item.name: Beer & Pretzels
item.comment: Well, more of a toy than a boardgame, it turned heads at out boardgame group meeting when we starting circling the table and cheering when all others were head-deep in Dominion and Ticket to Ride. A great party game (and drinking game I would think).

item.name: Beowulf: The Legend
item.comment:
This is by far my favourite Knizia game and I am not even a big fan of his designs. But this is a interesting an exciting bland of some randomness (drawing the cards), player interaction (bidding & bluffing) and planning ahead. Lovely game.
EDIT: Still a very well balanced and interesting game but is more fun when played with the right group.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment:
Very fiddly game and flimsy pieces which does not really affect the gameplay but it is just something I noticed, especially due to the fact that the game has been published by WOTC, one would expect better production values.
The game plays very counterintuitive and the board, character discs, cards and tokens are all very hard to make out and most of the game's downtime is generated by those issues. Furthremore, I am not a big fan of player elimination and in both games I played I ended up sitting around doing nothing for ages, not good.
Once the haunt starts, the chaos begins. The basic idea is nice but having two times 50 sets of rules each time you play makes it utterly chaotic and nobody really knows (and cares) what is going on anymore. In both games I played, all players were disinterested after a while.
A disappointment. HX

item.name: Beyond Balderdash
item.comment: To me, this is almost the perfect 'game', while others might challenge the very notion that this is a game in the first place. I can see where they are coming from but when I do measure the quality of a game by the amount of fun I have while playing it, this is on top of the list. Fantastic.

item.name: Bezzerwizzer
item.comment: One of the best quiz games out there. Interesting and lots of questions. Nice design and good range of topics. The added spice due to the special ability tokens (change topics, challenge opponenets) make it even more of an interesting game, especially when compard to dust collectors such as Trivial Pursuit and the like. The degree of difficulty varies quite a lot between questions sometimes and that can cause some distress, but then again, there is an equal chance to get an easy question for all teams

item.name: Bezzerwizzer +
item.comment:
I am big fan of the original Bezzerwizzer and I was excited to finally play this "Deluxe" version, even though it turned out to be a family (i.e. kids) version. This edition has three basic problems:
1. The rules are incredibly complicated. Not the basic flow of the game but what to do when playing the various categories. Takes way too much time to figure it out
2. The game is just way too easy. I did not get a single question wrong, neither did the others. No challange for adults. I feel like this is meant to be played with kids only
3. The game tries to be too much at the same time. The idea with the xylophone is neat, but there is remebering words, pictures, stories .... just too much cats in one bag to not cause confusion. Keep it simple. Do a Bezzerwizzer Memory or Bezzerwizzer Music, dont mash it up in one behemoth of a party game.
Shame really

item.name: Black Stories 7
item.comment: An interesting idea, but not much of a game in the finer sense of the word. Anyone who remembers the infamous riddles and ghost stories people would tell in camp or around the campfire, should be familiar with the concept behind this product. Some stories are more interesting than others, let alone believable or credible, so that makes for a slightly unbalanced drop in quality at times. Like so many communication games, the fun you will have depends highly on the group of people around the table.

item.name: Blag!
item.comment: Like many social games, this one is fun with the right people. Similar to Dixit or Nobody is perfect, this one is about making up answers that people fall for while guessing the right answer. This time, it is about captions for photos. However, not all pictures are as fun as some others, and some rounds will be way more pleasant than others and many "captions" can be guessed as there is only so much room for interpretation in a "real" photograph. I do prefer Nobody is perfect because knowing the right answer is almost impossible and the questions more varied. Also, I am not a big fan of games that involve writing and reading out answers as this usually drags the game down and issues with peoples' handwriting etc. distort the chances of some. Still, played with the right people, this one is an easy and nice way to end a gameday.

item.name: Bloody Legacy
item.comment: There is not really a game in here. Just playing random cards and waiting for others to be eliminated. The humour on the card is quirky but quite obnoxious as well. Not my kind of game (it is not a game in the first place)

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: Interesting game which could do with a bit more randomness even and diversity in cards and tiles, but I presume the designers tried to keep it simple. I found it odd (not bad mind you) that the game becomes easier in terms of resource abundance and possibilities. Yet, due to the fact that this goes for all players the race for the win becomes really fast towards the end instead of weighing and slowing down in the end like many other eurogames. The theme is terrible, generic semi-fantasy, a bit more effort would have been appreciated. Will definitely play again to see how it holds up.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: A cute little game with some neat mechanics. This game can really shine when you have people who take the whole trading shebang to heart and offer, negotiate and cause some sort of general market atmosphere to ignite. In general, i found the game to be quite close in the end, just because the "range" of points never really tilts out of the average. The theme itself is surprisingly cute and works well with the whole growing of plants thing.

item.name: Boomtown
item.comment: A simple game with enough interaction and ideas to make it slightly better than other efficiency engine games (RFTG / San Juan). The interaction is there, players' income is partially dependent on what other players do, are they building mines in your town, using your bar etc. The theme is plastered on but it works fine, alas, it is a bit too cartoonish for me but that does not matter much. Not a bad filler that is. HX

item.name: Bootleggers
item.comment: An interesting game with a light theme that works really well. There was not much backstabbing and thugging going on in our game but I can see it escalating and await more plays in anticipation of this. The game looks older than it is, like an MB or Parker game from the 90ies or 80ies, maybe that is why it has flown under the radar so far ? Good mechanics, plays quick and lots of interaction going on, deals, threates etc.

item.name: The Boss
item.comment: The basic idea is not bad, albeit nothing new or innovative. However, I feel that the game is either broken or terribly unpolished, The way players are distributing their cubes amongst the cities just does not feel right. You should not be allowed to pass and just wait for others to move first, unless their is either a benefit in going first or a penalty in going last. As it stands, I do not like this game, because I think they did not playtest and polish it thoroughly.

item.name: The Bottle Imp
item.comment: Maybe it was too late in the evening or my expectations were off but I found Bottle Imp to be an unnecessary complicated and confusing card game that does not add as much fun to the formula of cardgames as it adds rules and fiddlyness. Not for me.

item.name: Buccaneer
item.comment: A clever little game with a nice theme that works well, despite being so thinly spread over the game. The core mechanic, which is stacking your pirate discs on top of each other and thus making it possible to attack ships and still being able to see who is part of the crew in the first place is really what this game is all about. Good, keen to play more

item.name: Bunny Bunny Moose Moose
item.comment:
Yes, it is a really silly game and good fun to see your gaming friends sticking their tongues out but as a game, there is not much there. It is more or less an exercise in quick computing and visual perception (calculating the the best score based on the visual clues on the cards). What I did not like is the lack of interaction between the players, you could play this with two, or even on your own and it would almost be the same game.
EDIT: I enjoyed it slightly more this time than the last time I played it, but still, I know that the sole reason why I like to play this at all is to see my friends making funny faces and saying things with their tongue stretched out. All that tells me is that I should play more hands-on party games. Maybe not this one.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment:
I like games with an unique twist and pointing guns at other players can certainly be called as much. A good "social" game which does not really have an intriguing or game-shaping mechanics and I am yet to see players develop a "strategy" out of the mess and raucous. Anyhow, good for what it is and I am sure the advanced game will give it more flavour and edge.
EDIT: Yes, this is 'just' a bluffing game and a simple one for that but by measuring the amount of fun and laughter I experience when playing this game, this tops the ranks of my ratings, so there you go, 7.5 to 9.

item.name: Cadwallon: City of Thieves
item.comment: This is an okay game, nothing here that really excites me. It is more ore less a roll and move and die rolling game and that is what it comes down with a few exceptions thrown in here and there through cards and abilities. Not a clever game and not an innovative game but just plain and simple and worth your while if there is nothing else to do.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game
item.comment: Played this once and was very overwhelmed by all the icon struggles but on the other hand underwhelmed by strategic choices. Play as many characters as you can and just rush your opponent all the time. Love the theme and the artwork and that alone boosts its rating, but I am not sure about the game yet.

item.name: Candid Camera Game
item.comment: One from my dad's collection. More or less a race game and pretty much relies on the license, which of course could only appeal to collectors by now. Other than that, the game has a quirkyness and cult appeal. I would recommend this for nostalgia and Americana fans, but as a game, it is not very good.

item.name: Cannibal Pygmies in the Jungle of Doom
item.comment: The second expansion I bought for the Z-Man game line of collectible card decks (Grave Robbers etc.) I think the Cannibal & Jungle theme does not work as good as the other expansions. It does not feel as B-Movie esque as the others, because there are not many B-Movies concerned with jungle crawling out there. It adds nice touches to the basic game and should definitely be on the radar of Grave Robber fans, but maybe you should think about going for the other themed packs instead.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
My Dad and I have been playing this for years now and he loves it, so do I. The perfect balance between easy to learn, hard to master. I have not tried any of the expansion yet and I am looking forward to it.
EDIT: Played this a lot more times than I registered plays for. Still a great game, perfectly simple and addictive. Works great with 2-3 players.

item.name: Carcassonne: 2. Erweiterung – Händler und Baumeister
item.comment: The 2nd expansion adds loads of new tiles which makes the gameplay longer and your table needs more critical. The gameplay elements are nice and the expansion adds goods produced by your cities, pigs for the farms and building masters. The expansion is more elaborate than the 1st and I can highly recommend it.

item.name: Carcassonne: Die Erweiterung
item.comment: This adds some nice elements to the game, especially the cathedral is a nice addition as it is a risky card to lay down both for yourself as well as to spite your opponent. Not a lot for an expansion (three new concepts), but more would maybe throw the minimalist appeal of Carcassonne.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Castle
item.comment: An interesting rendition of classic Carcassonne which takes what is unique about Carcassonne (the freeform tile laying) and turns it on its head by introducing the spatial restriction which offers new strategic problems and perspectives. I like the scoring system and the random bonuses mix it up a little and break up the traditional non-luck Euro flow of the original game.

item.name: Carcassonne: The City
item.comment: Definitely the only Carcassonne-spin off I have enjoyed so far, which might come down to the fact that this is designed by the same designer as the original and it shows, not just some random company cashing in on the name. The game is definitely more complex and intricate than Carcassonne but not necessarily better. In fact, I still think the original is superior but this is a welcome spell of fresh air. The game takes a bit too long (with four players at least) for what it is, but never mind.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Discovery
item.comment: A nice Carcassonne variant, which feels different enough to warrant a new game I suppose. I feel that is plays quicker and is also more luck-based (or push your luck) than the original and less complicated (no farmers etc.). The artwork is nice as well and I actually prefer it over the original. Good if you want to play something like Carcassonne but burner out on the original. On the other hand, if you are looking for the superior experience, there is no reason not to choose the original, so this is more or less a novelty alternative.

item.name: Careers
item.comment: Used to play it with my dad, granny and brother. Nice game with lots of familiy appeal. Quite flexible, despite the simple mechanics. The goal of "making your career" is very universal and easy to get into.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment: A complex tile-laying, puzzle/efficiency game. The artworka and theme is amazing and what makes the game truly shine, I just wish that there would be a few more thematic things, like events or citizens with specific behaviours that influence the game etc. Still, there are dice and gunfights. It will take a few plays to get your head around the strategy, but that is the case with most games. Solid stuff.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: Played it once and did not like. I feel that even in the 'skill' game there is too much luck and randomness involved. Yes, in theory you might want to look out for what everyone else has when it comes to cards and which cards are available to draw but that is no 'fun' and feels like work and so everyone just tries to make the most of his cards and positions and let's see what happens. Not a bad idea, just too light for my taste.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons
item.comment: I played this game again and for some miraculous reason, I did enjoy it after all. It plays quick and the action choice mechanism is interesting and quite balanced when it comes to the interaction between player and makes things like turnorder very important for your strategy. It takes a while to grasph all the different possibilities (worker placement for VPs) but once you get it, it's cakewalk. I can see how some people might feel this game gives you too many options without doing anything to influence or steer your decision through events / phases etc, but there are always the winter cards to mix things up. Gorgeous artwork and a nice theme round this up. Good stuff !

item.name: The Castle of the Devil
item.comment: The game takes a long time to get going, the initial 5 minutes are very dull. The limited action more or less nullify some turns. With four players, this is very underwhelming and I am not sure what to think of a card game that is supposed to work with as few as three but needs at least 6 to shine, it is rarely going to happen. Neat idea but the execution is a bit lacklustre.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Not much about this that interests me. Only limited strategy and interactivity and I really do not like the way the game cannot decide whether it is a cooperative or competitive game and as such and I never feel like I know what I am doing or should be doing, not a good sign when playing a game. The artwork is not nice and almost abstract, the could have put more effort in emulating the theme. Too simple and generic for me.

item.name: Catan Dice Game Plus
item.comment: Just another Yahtzee Clone. Roll the Dice and try to get the right combos in three attempts in order to buy the necessary items (here: roads, cities, etc) to give you the most victory points. With more than one players, people just take turns into playing solitaire and compare points at the end. Why no trading of dice or stealing of dice ? Or limited supplies or locations to build ? Not enough interaction to make it worth your while playing this with others.

item.name: Catan: Seafarers
item.comment: I prefer the original Catan, I am not sure what this might add to the game apart from the odd imbalance depending on the scenario, making the board lopsided or uneven, more than it is in the first place.

item.name: Cathedral
item.comment: Found it for 1 Pound at a Charity Shop in London. A very "simple" game, in terms of rules at least. I do like the game very much, I do have the wooden pieces edition and it the bits look and feel great, like chess pieces. When I played this game I noticed that players will quickly start to create strategies and try out tactics, becoming more involved in the game. The game does not work well with players of different playing strength, because there is no luck involved at all.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: CITOW is definitely a FFG game. You can tell by the mechanics, the bits and the theme. But also because it is a mixture of other FFG games, effectively it borrows a lot from Middle Earth Quest, BSG and War of the Ring. Anyhow, it is a good game and all the Ameritrash laurels are in there, various player powers, flavouring, global effects, specific effects, dice and so forth. I never played Warhammer before but I feel it emulates the gritty world quite well. The strategies are varied and I enjoyed how the outcome could not be predicted by the veteran player. Still, I would have been more impressed by this if it was not for many similar games by FFG I have player before.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: Of course I 'like' chess. But I am not a big fan of Abstract games, especially those that involve no luck. I am in awe that this game is so old and still playable but is it fun ? Not sure, it is definitely a good challenge and a rewarding experience but I find it a bit too stressful and hard in order to enjoy it with my feet kicked up.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: A neat cutthroat negotiation game. And when I say negotiation, I pretty much summarised the game already. The whole game hinges on the players' willingness to take part on frantic, fun and feisty negotiations with each other. Imagine Settlers of Catan's trading phase: The game and you almost know all Chinatown is about. The theme and art is neat but more or less pasted on. Like the game, but I can see how some might fail to actually see the game in here (lack of mechanics) but to me, the interaction is where it's at anyway, so I enjoy this kind of game.

item.name: La Città
item.comment: The game is actually less complicated than it looks and despite some fiddly stuff and not very elegant design (not the mechanics but the upkeep of available food, population limit etc.). I like that there are really not a lot of victory conditions like in many other games and even though there are always quite a few choices to be made, the focus never derails and the goal is clear. I wish the game would have more streamlined and you make a lot of mistakes just because there are so many things to keep track of and the game does not help you in doing it. The game is confrontational without being vicious because if you steal people, you have to feed them after all. Maybe it could have done with a bit more card variety and randomness, but that would probably made it much less of a euro.

item.name: Civilization
item.comment:
Me and my friends played this and we spend whole nights with this game. I found the history theme a bit heavy and dry (I was 12 for god's sake) but enjoyed it more as I got older. A nice game, not for non-gamers though. Simple in mechanics, yet epic in scope.
EDIT: Played it again after almost 15 years. Still enjoy it, good pre-Euro / Euro mechanics although there is a lot of counting and bookkeeping involved which makes the game unnecessary fiddly and number-crunchy. Still, a great game. I will have to play this with more players in order to evaluate its true potential though.
EDIT2: Played it again for the second time and it dragged on a bit. I feel that there is not enough happening to warrant the prolonged playing time and the calamities felt really unbalanced (flood does nothing sometimes, famine can wipe out an entire civilization). I noticed that the fun factor depends on how you play this game with. With wargamers and heavy euro games, Civ is lots of fun, but for connoisseurs of modern and more streamlined games, Civ can be quite tedious.

item.name: Clans
item.comment: The basic idea is not bad but the game does not click with me. You just do some semi-random abstract moves and hope for the best. When we played, the whole concept of keeping you colour hidden, as appealing as it sounds in theory did not matter at all and we just tried to maximize points. The player who tried to hide his colour until closer to the end, came in third. I am sure there is some strategy to it but even if you would figure it out, how many meaningful and complex (satisfying) decisions are there to be made in this game ? Not a lot I reckon.

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment: The game is definitely more flexible than it first looks with only two types of monster miniatures and three types of heroes, not a lot of cards etc. The scenarios make it interesting and it is definitely more interesting both in theme and in execution than the similar Castle Ravenloft but I still think it is a shame this was not produced by FFG who could have beefed it up with content and just more of the same instead of this careful 'light' approach which needs more expansions to be the milestone it could be. A bit more flavouring (in the bits and tiles) as well as in the rules and on the cards would have been nice too.

item.name: The Climbers
item.comment: An interesting spatial puzzler, that is almost more of a toy than a game. I am not sure there is a lot of strategy to it, more a question of tactics, but the winner can pretty much be decided by one or two moves in the end instead of any sort of long-term performance throughout the game. Maybe this is a good thing and the game would be too harsh if people would be eliminated too early but this means it also feels like you have less control. Still, the way it breaks the mold of your usual boardgame experience is definitely worth the time.

item.name: Clue Mysteries
item.comment: Despite being advertised a different game experience from Clue, it is still a matter of running around on the board and gathering clues. While the players cared for the story in the first few games, after a while they stopped paying attention because the story does not matter anyway, and the game became pure dice rolling.

item.name: Clue: The Great Museum Caper
item.comment: Enjoyed playing this with my dad. It is a good variant of the hidden movement game (such as Scotland Yard or Fury of Dracula). The artwork and playing pieces are very nice and the mechanics work well. I also enjoyed being subject to motion alarms and cameras. A nice way to track the bad guys movement was to actually nick the paintings from the gameboard, which added greatly to the rage of the detective and the fun.

item.name: Colonial: Europe's Empires Overseas
item.comment: Might be my favourite global colonization game I have played so far, love the card programming mechanic and the many ways to victory.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment:
A neat little cardgame which takes up more place than your usual cardgame. Basically a trick taking game with two severe differences. A. There is more than one active pile of cards in on the table B. You can "choose" which colours give you a bonus and which ones a minus.
Two little elements which make the Coloretto experience unique. There is enough tactics and strategy to make it engaging but not too much to undermine the basic idea of a swift card game. Colours work better than numbers anyhow and Coloretto does that right.
Nice Filler.
HX

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment:
I like this game although there are some points of criticism I have. The game does not change as you get further into the game and repeating the five steps over and over again is a bit dull at time. Also, and that might have been due to the group I played with, the auctioning and trading was not that exciting and most of the time there was none of either. So, it more or less came down to the inital tile draw and a bit of luck.
Lovely components though I just do not see more than the sum of its parts.

item.name: Concept
item.comment: An interesting "game", even though I consider it more of a collaborative creative activity, like Charades. The "rules" are not actual rules at all and as soon as you get going, you toss the "rules" and scoring system overboard anyway and start having fun with the board and cubes. Still, it might be a tad too free-for-all for actual gamers and I would suggest playing this with a good mixture of gamers and non-gamers, maybe even the latter exclusively.

item.name: Condottiere
item.comment: A card game that pretends to be an area control game. The board does not add a whole lot to the game but I suppose it is slightly more interesting than just adding up some scores on a sheet or moving a cube up a point scale. The game is good and more tactical than it would seem at first glance. I still think that some of the cards are overpowered and can win the game too soon and too easily and that can be frustrating.

item.name: Confusion: Espionage and Deception in the Cold War
item.comment: Very well produced and gorgeous Stratego clone with a big chunk of deduction thrown it. Might not appeal to lighter games because it is a bit of a brain burner despite its very simple rules but then again it feels like and old/classic game, so friends of Stratego or Chess might like it. The theme is okay, but the production value makes up for it. Great idea to make the assignment of movement capabilities with the pieces random !

item.name: Connect 4 (Revised Edition)
item.comment: As simple as it gets. Unfortunately, the fun wears off pretty fast and I cannot really play it for longer than 30 minutes without being bored. Nice game for kids though.

item.name: Conquest of Planet Earth: The Space Alien Game
item.comment: Played this for the first time today and enjoyed the theme and artwork (thank god no photographs!), but I found the cooperative game a tad bit non-interactive. No joined battles or strategies really. Still, a good fun, action-romp with simple rules but lots of exceptions. Will definitely play again.

item.name: La Cosa Nostra
item.comment:
I was lucky enough to play this little gem with the designer during a protoype session, when he brought along the game to Cologne on Board. Given that this game is still in development, I wont write a full review but a lengthy comment instead.
The theme is captured very nicely, both in terms of the visual style (reminiscient of GTA) and mechanics, with lots of potential screwage, careful planning that can go wrong, some risk taking, some limited luck and of course negotiations and fragile alliances. Some people on the other table said, overhearing us play sounds like an episode of Breaking Bad and that is not far off ...
Every round (a total of four) you associate an action / order card with one of your gangsters of varyiing strength. Once the whole planning is done, you have to choose the order in which you execute the former, which can work out as perfectly as you planned it but can go horribly wrong as well, either out of bad luck (rarely) or because someone double-crosses you or sabotages you in some way (more often than one would wish for). Then again, doing the same to other Dons is a hella lot of fun.
Despite a tangible lack of in-game controlled balance mechanics (leader bashing and trailing off is both very well possible), the players I played with restored the balanced and the finish was very close, for a game featuring such an liberal degree of player-guided targeting.
I found the negotiations particularly delightful, because only a very (!) limited number are binding and many other deals a based on pure trust - but are actually based on some evil plan, revenge, vendetta or sheer meaningness more often than not.
All in all, I found this to a very exciting mixture of action planning, negotiation (interaction) and some luck. It might be a bit too harsh and confrontational for some family/Euro-Gamers, but then again, this game might not be for them.
My only drawback (after one play mind you, maybe it is just a wrong initial impression) is the lack of a catch-up mechanism.
Kudso to the game designer for demoing his game at a local game group with such patience, passion and - most of all - fun.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: My My, how expectations can be wrong, at least so it appears. This has been on my must-have list for quiet some time, despite the fact that I never played it. Now, I had the pleasure of trying it for the first time and was royally flabbergasted by it. It is a very simple game, which is not a bad thing, but it is so random and yet at the same time limited in its possible strategic decisions that I never really experienced the sensation of playing a 'game' in the true sense of the word but experiencing a cascade of random events unfolding before my eyes. The destiny cards are the first thing that I found bizarre, if you cannot choose who to attack, the winner of the game can solely be determined by card draw. Yes, yes, you might form alliances, but who would ally with you unless necessary anyway and then, where is the strategical decision ? Same goes for defending. The abilities are a good idea, but I found that too far in the game-breaker instead of tactic enhancer field. All in all, I am still astonished by the mediocrity of this game and will most definitely have to play it again and make sure whether it was just a one-off bad experience.

item.name: Coup
item.comment: Quite an interesting "Alternative" to The Resistance or other "hidden identity" games in the same vain. Yet, I found this to be quite hard to get into. Maybe because it takes quite a few plays to learn all the roles by heart, but remembering who claimed to be what and when the players swapped their (alleged) roles through the ambassador is not as easy at it sounds. Still, I am curious to see how the experience might change once I play it a few more times, but for now, I would prefer The Resistance or Werewolf. Also, I found that more than once, there was only one choice left ( and one possible winner left) in the game, something I dont really like in games.

item.name: Cranium
item.comment: Cranium is one of the best family/friends/party games, using the usual charades, trivia questions, drawing challenges and the forth. Of course, the game walks and falls with the players you surround yourself with. If they are resistent to singing, acting or whistling, you will have no fun at all. I am not saying this is not a good party game, but I am not a fan of the genre in general.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment: A pretty heavy euro-game, not because the mechanics or concepts are much deeper or more complex than other euro-games but the designers clearly had no intention of keeping it focused and simple and added lots of different things that go on at the same time. The game could have worked with 2 out of 4 of the present core mechanics/engines but then it might have been whole different and much lighter game. I do like it, although I think there could have been more variety when it comes to the buildings (random order) and events, but what gives. A good game and gorgeous to look at.

item.name: Curse of the Idol
item.comment: Played this game to pieces when I was a kid. Found it amazingly appealing and exciting. I would love to play it again, maybe have a go at it with my girlfriend. The pulp-Indy theme is one of my favourites and there are not many games around which pull it off.

item.name: Da Capo!
item.comment: It's been a long time since I have played this, I remember enjoying moderately. Very simple and uninnovative game mechanics.

item.name: Dakota
item.comment: I did enjoy it to a certain degree. I like the 'theme'. although it is more or less an euro resource gathering game. One of the players dubbed it as 'maybe-cooperative' and that nails it. Indians or Cowboys can decide to work together in order to prevent the other faction from getting the edge when it comes to acquiring resources. However, in our game, the players just kept screwing each other randomly and it kind of took the fun out for me. As much as I like to win a game, I cannot back-stab people, so any game that requires me to do so is not really my cup of tea. I would definitely play this again, but only with the right people.

item.name: Dancing Eggs
item.comment: Another hit by HABA, love these guys. This game is fun because things go wrong when people are trying to hold on to their eggs and dance around the table and do all sorts of ungodly things ! Great fun ! Must be played with people who don't mind having fun.

item.name: David & Goliath
item.comment: A clever card game. It takes a few plays to get your head around but once you start developing strategies you will notice that it is very well balanced and you will always be so close to the perfect set and something or someone will jeopardize it and you are keen to try again.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: Played this at my local game club and enjoyed it very much. It reminded me of HeroQuest. In my opinion, a few game mechanics too many and not enough random element triggers too make the game more non-tactic dependent. But still, I am looking forward to playing this more and maybe owning at some point.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment: Finally played the first few levels a few times with newbies and am now ready and willing to start a full fledged campaign (and found someone who is keen to do the same, yay!). So, I am looking forward to many more plays of this and then on to buying all the expansions ... oh boy.

item.name: Diplomacy
item.comment: Much better than I expected after hearing so many horror stories, but I can see how this might go awfully wrong. Our group was fantastic, many of my close friends and easy going newcomers. But, the game itself is not really what makes or breaks the experience but the players and my rating incorporates the assumption that you play with the right group, because the game itself, in terms of design and intrinsic value is not necessarily that great (the basic idea is good). Still, a fantastic experience.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Your Dixit experience really depends on who you are playing it. Playing it with hardcore gamers will result in consecutive moaning about how this is not a game. Playing it with geeks will result in myriads of LOTR and Dr. Who references being thrown around the table. If you play it with a healthy mix of open minded people it is great fun. Lots of laughs and great insights into peoples' personalities. The scoring system is incredibly confusing though and nobody, inlcluding the owner did not get it. Lovely game.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment:
The game is not as complex at people have you think, at least the rules are not. The most complex issue with this game is the fact that all actions are available from the very beginning. Of course, some of them do not make a whole of sense at first and chosing them as your action might be quite foolish, but it is a long and winding road until you figure that out for yourself. The game is quite abstract and so are the 'depictions' of the species, dominance and so forth (cubes, cones), but the flow of the game and the dynamic of conflicting species is very on theme and has been a surprisingly involving experience even if compared with games which are actually trying to be thematic (and are not). The final scoring is kind of overpowered in my opinion but that is not too bad. The game takes a long time and really melts your brain, I wonder if you could play it with less cards (12 and the Ice Age card) ? Anyhow, a good game and if it was not for the time and effort it takes to play this, I would have rated it much higher.
EDIT: Played again and the same thing happened AGAIN. Rush for empty tiles at the end and too much chaos that really unbalanced the game. Rating slipped down. For a game that takes this long and feels so intricate, there are too many things and special abilities that throw the balance.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment:
Finally got around to play it and am a bit disappointed. For a boardgame, it is not very interactive and every player is kind of brewing his own soup and you can pretty much play the game while ignoring the other players. Especially with experienced players / seasoned players, the game plays very fast and more like a quick game of cards (without any bluffing/betting etc), rendering the in-game communication to a minimum. The theme is quite generic and I would have prefered a more gritty setting, dark ages instead of medieval. I quite like the idea of a new and random set up of cards each time you play, but overall. the player-player interactivity is way too limited for a boardgame.
EDIT: I had the chance to play it again with three out of four players (including me) being newbies and inexperienced and I had more fun this time. I actually noticed what was going on and at least attempted to think of something which remotely resembled a strategy. I reckon if I would play this game with a bunch of new players who play this game SLOWLY (what is it with some geeks, going for the speed record, how fast can I play the game?), I would enjoy it more. I think Dominion can be played fast, but I would rather play it with people that take longer to make their move and give me more time doing mine. Anyway, I like it better than the first time and I will play it again, but I am still not convinced it is such a great game. HX

item.name: Downfall
item.comment: Enjoyed this as a kid. It was fun being concealed behind the "wall" and bluffing and scheming to get your chips through. A fun game, especially for kids. It feels a lot like an actual toy.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: Not as good as I though it might turn out to be. The basic idea is great and the asymmetrical game design is pretty neat, but I still found that there was never much strategy to my decision. On the other hand, maybe that is why I did not win and I should play again to see if the strategy is not hidden under some rocks ? A good game, but not fantastic. I will have to play it again and the rating can go either way.

item.name: Dragon's Gold
item.comment: I am impressed by game designers that are courageous enough to rely on pure and solid communication to solve in-game issues, especially if the core principle on the game is built upon that very aspect. A cutthroat negotiation game. If the time runs out, nobody gets the loot. This game can really go awkward when played with the wrong people but I do like my games dangerous now and then and it can really spice up and evening of dusty euros.

item.name: Dragonology: The Game
item.comment: A simple and chaotic racing game. Good for kids and for adults that really like their dragons. The minitatures and artwork are great (except the board though). Still, for kids who are into the Dragonology books, this is fun. As a game, it is oddly underwhelming, and 80 % of the game is luck, rolling the dice, drawing cards and so forth, to put it plainly, the game is an eccentric form of waiting. HX

item.name: Drako
item.comment: A pretty and simple confrontational, almost abstract 2-player game. Not sure who repetitive it can get because I think there are only a handful, if not less, good tactics for either side and the rest comes down to lucky draws. But still, lovely board and miniatures and quick playing time make this a keeper for me.

item.name: Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner
item.comment: As an avid fan of Ameritrash, randomness and dice rolling, this game is supposably right up my alley. I played in a bit of rush and withouth indulging in the flavour texts and really enjoying what makes this game unique, the bizarre mixture of characters, weapons etc. from all ages and the odd combinations and 'stories' it creates. So my rating is more or less for the mechanics and the basic idea but I must play this again, with more time and dedication to the flavouring in order to really evalaute what it could do for me. I think the multitude of availbale skills makes it unnecessary fiddly. Why not stick with Strenght, Intellgence, Speed and leave it at that ? Still, a great game.

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment: Way too fiddly for my taste. I dont like the idea of each player having his own little boards. It might work for Puerto Rico but it does not for Dungeon Lords, it feels like playing a solitaire game with some people sticking around. The only fun elements are those in which players "sort of" interact, but that element is orphaned within the rest of the overloaded rulesfest. Not my kind of thing.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: Played this game for the first times(s) today and fairly enjoyed it. However, the game is a bit too simple for me and the theme (I loathe the "world" of Dungeons & Dragons) is too generic. The game features your usual random mix of supersimplified post-Tolkien wash outs, ranger,cleric, fighter, skeletons, ghoul etc., nothing new but old ideas recycled into something worse. The game itself is rather repetitive and I am not sure whether this will change with later scenarios (played the 1st and 6th). Furthermore, it looks like WOTC supplied the minimum amount of monsters, scenarios and heroes only to make this heavily expendable and cash in. If you compare the amount of bits and bobs in this game with the similar Descent or Arkham Horror, it looks pathetic. All in all, a nice dungeon romp and probably and nice fantasy-gateway game but unless I get in in a trade, I cannot see myself purchasing it at any point in the future.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Fantasy Adventure Board Game
item.comment: A very basic HeroQuest clone. I still prefer HeroQuest over this game though as I was never fond of the D&D world. The miniatures and pieces are much nicer and the variety of items makes looting much more fun. But I found the scenarios included, apart from being not many, rather uninteresting and not maximizing what you could have gotten out of this game system.

item.name: Duplik
item.comment: I am a sucker for partygames because it combines all out I love about gaming. Communication, fun, getting to know other people, involving a lot of people etc. Identik is no exception, it is great fun and should go down a roar with friends and family. I can see people running out of cards fairly quickly though, but other than that, brilliant idea. HX

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment:
Played this Essen 2011 hype monster only once. It is a neat game but all in all, it is not as good as people make it out to be, at least, not for me. The theme does not interest me at all. Whenever people moan about the same old generic fantasy mumbo jumbo, like orcs, elves and dwarfs, I get excited, I am a post-Tolkien man through and through. But talk to me about wormholes, plasma guns and planets and I start snoring sooner than you can say 'Bones McCoy'.
Apart from that, I found that the game lacks interaction, where is the trading, diplomacy, sweat-inducing negotiations, alliances, laws that bind you you to do certain things, interactive victory conditions (apart from wars. Most of the time, I found that people just build and dwell on their little separate boards in Agricola style and I general don't like games where people have their own boards, that spells multi-solitaire like nothing else.
Also, just like many 'old' wargames (Game of Thrones / Risk), this game has no catch-up or balancing mechanism in place for players who get left behind. Unlucky tile draw in the first few rounds ? Tough cookies, you are probably out of the winner's race for good. Two players decide to crush the last player and eliminate him from the game ? Call your grandma, your coming home, but the game does not help you at all. How about bonus chips for whoever has the lowest in science, resources and money each turn ? Something like that would cut it, so the design, while elegant and polished is outdated in my opinion.
On the upside, I do like the playing time, rules are clear and the design feels polished so that the flow of the game is very good, when compared to similar games such as Twilight Imperium.
If you love space games that are a tad dry and Euro, this is for you. To me, it feels more like space tax return than space opera, too much work, not enough fun.

item.name: Eight-Minute Empire: Legends
item.comment: A rather light Euro game disguised as a fantasy-themed light wargame without the (direct) confrontation and bloated rules. Most of the crux in this game lies in positioning and moving your cubes to gain dominance and majority in specific areas, depending on your VP conditions and cards. The variable leaders add more layers to the tactics without breaking the game, because we are talking about 1, maybe 2 points here. Yet, I found the limited interaction a bit dissapointing. Of course, you can keep your eyes peeled and observe what cards the others are picking and which winning course they are going for but most of the time your are concerned with complimenting your deck with new cards. Also, I found this a tad too light to fill the slot of the main dish in a game night but too complex to be a filler, let alone the fact that it does not bring anything new to the table (the alleged playing time of 8 minutes comes to 8 minutes per person for sure).

item.name: Eketorp
item.comment: Interesting bluffing game (both in terms of placing the meeples as well as during fighting). I can see how this game may fall flat if people become annoyed at backstabbing and random attacks but if you get into the spirit of crazy viking attacks and so forth, this is something for you.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: A lighter version of Struggle of Empires. Less direct conflict and no alliances. Still, a neat efficiency machine game with enough interaction to make it worthwhile. The rules are simple but there are many strategies to go for and many options you have, especially in the early stage of the game. A bit more randomness would have please my chaotic nature but it does not feel incomplete without. Neat and tranquil artwork etc. rounds the experience up. Good one.

item.name: Epaminondas
item.comment: An abstract chess like game. While not as deep and complex and chess, it still enjoyable for its simple mechanics and rules.

item.name: Escape from Atlantis
item.comment:
As a kid, I found the prospect of the gameboard being a sinking island amazing and I reckon I still would. Although I tweaked the rules heavily to turn it into a sort of Survival/Disaster game, the base game is quite good as well and a nice way for kids to be introduced in fantasy boardgaming.
EDIT: I played this again and found it really fun. Nice components and screwage without being too serious.
EDIT2: Played it once more and found it a bit longish and too random

item.name: Essence: The Game of Insights
item.comment:
A very fun and interesting 'get to know each other' variant which is all about people guessing about values, traits etc. and how they relate to the other players and the group in general. A good game and with the right group, social and funny people, this is a big hit. Still, the game in here lies in enjoying the company, there are not a lot of mechanics here, although there are still more than it all other games of this kind I played so far.
EDIT: Played it again and I found it a bit too complicated to drawn people in for what it is. Not enough game to engage people but too much to explain to interest people in the first place. Also, many of the concepts in the games are just too abstract to be interesting unless people are willing to talk and discuss them during gameplay which most of the won't be ready to do. I do like the idea of this, but the execution is just to naive and will not work as a game.

item.name: Evil Genius: Deathray
item.comment: I rated this a "1" just because I can. Never played it nor know anything about it. But some people rated it a 10 to advertise it (obviously). So I am playing The Master of Eternal Justice and there you go - a neat little "1" for the game.

item.name: Expedition Sumatra
item.comment:
I think the game itself is not bad, even quite interesting, the boats moving around the board is a neat idea and makes for some hard decisions. The randomness is fine and there is some interaction, although screwing other people ultimately hurts yourself so I felt like there was a tendency to leave each other alone. Anyhow, the reason while I will never play this game again and while I rate it so low is the horrible theme.
Players kidnapping animals from an island and selling them to Zoos ? What is this ? The insane prisoner design company ? That is the most awful theme I have seen in ages, no way this will go down well with families, kids or people who like animals, so almost all gamers. Rubbish, whoever came up with it should be smacked around. So many themes would have done the same if not a better job, treasure hunters in the jungle for example ! Anyhow, average game, terrible theme, stay away.

item.name: Exploding Kittens
item.comment: Great fun, push-your-luck game with a quite ludicrous theme. There is lots of luck involved but some hand management can steer the wheel of luck your way.

item.name: Eye Guess
item.comment: Out of my Dad's collection. A nice mix of memory and trivia. Some of the answers and questions are a bit odd due to their age, but in my opinion this adds to its playbility because the game is not as knowledge dependent as it probably used to be and relies more on the memory aspect. The theme should appeal to Nostalgia and Americana Fans.

item.name: Familien-Duell
item.comment: I play this with my family. The mechanics need heavy tweaking as replaying the "game show" can be quite tedious. Yet, trying to figure out what other people's answers to questions could have been is a nice twist to the trivia genre.

item.name: Farlander
item.comment: I have played this only once. While it seems very simple at first glance, there is more room for tactics / strategy than one might expect. Although this is what what makes this game a bit bland and unexciting as well. From the set-up to the conquering phase, there is no single element of luck or randomness, so it is all skill and strategy. A experienced player will wipe out a new player every time, not a bonus for me.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment:
I enjoyed this more than I thought I would because I am not a big fan of Friedmann Friese, mainly due to this themes. This game is very simple but good. The core mechanics are bluffing and bidding as well as reading the other players. Well balanced.
EDIT: Played it a few times and found it can be a tad too random an unpredictable what to do and some of the guesswork is more luck than anything else (although it is of course another player's decision)

item.name: Feudal
item.comment: A chess-variant of medieval war. Different unit types with various powers and movement patterns battle it out on a large and abstract plastic landscape. Nice game, a bit more theme than chess, but not as flexible and complex.

item.name: Fjords
item.comment: An interesting little hybrid of minimalistic tile-laying and Go, the player first build an island and place their farms and in the second part of the game try to take over as much land as possible while cutting off the opponents. Simple and nice filler game. HX

item.name: Flash Duel
item.comment: A very simple game, inspired by Knizia's "En Garde" (it actually says that in the rulebook). A 2 player duel game with two characters moving across a bidirectonial board, attacking, pushing and dashing towards each other. Whoever hits wins the round (Best of 3). The game is very simple, cards are number 1 to 5 with 5 cards of each in the deck. Players use those cards to move spaces or attack (with the number being the distance). You can either block or retreat with the right cards, but if cannot do either, you lost. There are 10 characters in the game which have clearly been inspired by old-school beat-em up's (think Street Figher etc.) which makes sense as a theme considering the game depicts the "duel" between two characters. The characters come with three special abilities which add a bit more strategy although I found that they come into play rarely. All in all, a good filler game but there are tons of games out there I'd rather buy, better 2-player games or games with more visual appeal. HX

item.name: For Fame & Fortune
item.comment: An interesting take on Texas Hold em. Adds two additional elements to the game that make it not much more interesting but much more complicated so I am not sure why people would play this instead of Poker. I though it was okay.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: An interesting game with two distinct phases. The theme is pretty much non-existent and it is just a numbers game, but still good fun. Mostly a game about reading your opponents.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: I prefer this over Pandemic. I like the theme and also the core mechanics which are essentially the same as Pandemic without all the bookkeeping and fiddlyness of the orginal game. We only played the normal difficulty and barely made it so there is plenty of challenge still to come. Hardcore gamers and strategist will probably find this underwhelming but I think it is a good light/family game to have in the collection.

item.name: Formula Dé
item.comment: Despite its popularity, this game is really not my cup of tea. I found it too fiddly, with all the counting all the time and too luck-driven as compared to other, slicker racing games (such as Ave Caesar). I am not into motorsports, so the theme really puts me off.

item.name: Formula Motor Racing
item.comment: Too random and no long-term strategy possible as too much relies on card draws and die rolls. Also, terrible theme. Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Founding Fathers
item.comment:
The flavouring on this is really amazing. Although the theme (politics / debate) is not really "implemented" because debates cannot really implemented into a boardgame (or can they, anyone fancy a challenge ?). Anyhow, it comes down to some middleweight euro brain teaser puzzling, figuring out how to score the most points. The cards and the respective events on them spice up the game and make it a tad more dynamic although some or way too overpowering and that does really not go well with theme (I would not mind anarchic and chaotic gameplay in a game other than debating founding fathers but it feels misplace in this one and kind of imbalances the game quite a bit). I love the flavour texts, the information about the delegates and articles and am looking forward to playing this with history buffs.
Great one. HX

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: How this game could be considered to be awarded Spiel des Jahres is beyond me. The mechanics are recycled from a dozen other games and there is nothing unique, new, let alone interesting about them. Auction off turn order, secret action allocation and some area control and that's it. Another thing I do not like about this game is that wit and cleverness will not get you as far as analytical strategy, which is something that I don't want in my games. I want negotiation, assumptions, uncertainty, luck, randomness. Anyhow, Fresco is a mediocre (at best) euro.

item.name: Funfair
item.comment: I see what they did here. A collection of little games that emulate the feeling of being at a funfair. Sadly, it is more of a novelty item and all games are more or less just mini-games, that is, simple games with one or two mechanics that resemble other games. It is fun seeing your fellow players getting silly for once but as a game, this is an epic fail. My buddy bought this because he is a fan of the Brand design team, but I did not see their magic working in this game at all! Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment: Unlike many of my other gaming friends, I do not think this game is hilarious at all. So you're all having sex and taking drugs (you wish!) - What is so funny about that ?
