It's like being stuck in a loop of Southpark reruns, not funny once you think about it. The game is not bad but very luck based, what cards come up and what cards are in your hand. There is some planning etc. but not enough to make this worthwhile in my opinion.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment:
Love this game. Finally got around playing it. Only downside is that it does not work to well with 2 players or 4 (downtime), so you really need to have 3 players or 5. You cannot solo it as well. Other than that. Amazing.
EDIT: The combat system is interesting on first sight but not varied enough to make it truly exciting with only a handful of cards available in the game at all. The same system would be great within a framework of mabye a hundred cards. Also, make sure to play this with Ameritrasher, all others will find the game boring.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: A rather clever game design and deceiptively simple because all you have to do in this game is create a spaceship out of tiles, more or less, a puzzle game, nothing more. But it is still fun, because the idea of competing against the other players who are also trying to create the perfect spaceship is great. I do not second the opinion that the exploration phase is no fun, I think it is but I can see how some might find it too random and non-decision based. A good game.

item.name: Game of Games
item.comment: Not a bad marketing idea, just make a games that included many other mini versions of other games. It was fun as a kind, if not for anything else, than for being so elaborate and unususal.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment: Never enjoyed the game. I found the premise uninteresting and the mechanics way too based on dice rolling.

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: An interesting update on the simultaenous action idea of Diplomacy with a spiced up setting that does a lot for A Game of Thrones fans and not much for people who have not read the book (like me), the game mechanisms are easier and more streamlined when compared to Diplomacy but it would be a stretch to call them elegant. The game is balanced not by in-game mechanisms (catch-up) but by the players itself and that is something I don't really like about wargames, and Game of Thrones for that matter. Once a player is behind, he is dependent on the mercy of others if he ever wants to catch up again and even if he does, he will be hard pressed to play a role in the outcome of the game as a whole. Apart from that, an okay game but boiling down a fantasy saga into nothing but a sophisticated risk variant does not really appeal to me. Like all games of this type, I enjoy the company more than the game itself.

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.comment: Interesting dungeon crawler, but I am not fond of the theme, never played the computer game so it does not do much for me, The components are good but the artwork on the tiles is a bit bland. Only played the first scenario so it felt a bit underwhelmed.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: An euro-puzzler disguised as light Ameritrash game. While I do like cooperative games with a theme, I feel like this theme is spread too thin on the game, with the drawings looking like the come from the back of a cereal box and if compared to other theme-driven games (AH and FOD) this looks really generic and bland. Furthermore, it is a puzzler and brainburner and due to the lack of flavour texts, theme implementation and randomness, the theme is soon forgotten and people will concentrate on solving the game. The random setup is nice, although I do not like the colourcoding of monsters which gives the game less flexibility.

item.name: Ghosts!
item.comment: A deceptively simple game, Jekyll & Hyde (or Ghosts) is like Stratego Super-lite. Both players move their pawns across the board, both movement and "combat" is resolved by the same rules, just move sideways, fore- or backwards. Both players have to take out the four "correct" pawns of the enemy, while preventing from having your own takes. The crucial thing is however, that the other players cannot tell which of your eight pawns are the one he is supposed to catch. Thus, there is a lot of bluffing going on, luring the opponent into attacking the wrong pawns etc. A great and quick game. HX

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: An interesting and quick playing Post-Carcassone variant (which resembles 20th Century quiet a bit). I like the theme, despite being very light. A handful of nice balancing mechanics make the game interactive enough to be interesting, although I would have prefered - again - if players would build on the same landscape instead of creating your own little Scotland in front of you.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: A solid cardgame with a fantastic theme and artwork which really is what makes the game fun to play. Reading out the flavour text on the cards is tremendously entertaining if played with the right folks with a gloomy disposition. The game is good as well and the translucent cards and the ability to stack one on the other with some still being visible etc. is an unique mechanic and the most interesting aspect of the game. HX

item.name: Gloom: Unhappy Homes
item.comment: Cannot really evaluate this expansion. I played it once and the new "homes" did not really add much to the game. HX

item.name: Die Goldene Stadt
item.comment: Rather light family/Euro game. The artwork and presentation is nice, although the victory point papers are awful. I feel that the game is imbalanced in parts (the bonus 2 points / some of the bonus cards), but I reckon this is just the underlying family nature of the Euro game, making it less cutthroat and more luck-based in parts OR maybe I need to play it more to see how close the scores are and whether there are multiple paths to victory. Not as much interaction/confrontation as I though there would be, but still a neat game.

item.name: GOSU
item.comment: Another recent card game that takes inspiration from the recent deck-building post-Magic trend. The theme does not do much for me, I have never been a fan of the 'Silly Greenskins' approach that has been made popular by GW and this is no exception. I am more of a Tolkien-Orc kind of guy. Anyhow, theme aside (the artwork is not that bad), the game is pretty decent, but just like many cardgames of this type, it feels a tad solitaire. Most of the time, people are just pondering over their own card display and figuring out what to do next, occasionally influencing the other players' game to a limited degree. It is this lack of interactivity that my biggest complain would be, I can see how you might almost be able to play this solitaire as the majority of the rules are concerned with the efficiency of your army structure than playing off your opponents' game. Also, the game just takes too long, I would have been happy to play this game for half the length I had to when I sat down and played it for the first time and that is not a good sign. So, shorten it and maybe add some Interaction and I am up for it.

item.name: Grave Robbers From Outer Space
item.comment: A nice and quirky game in the vain of "battle" CCGs. The theme really makes this work for me and I still enjoy looking at the cards and reading them while playing. The many available expansions add greatly to the value.

item.name: Great Western
item.comment: The game started out quite interesting, I liked the way the three dice create a random set of available trains for each turn, but the map really breaks the game. The endgame is definitely broken and whoever managed to go up to Wales wins the game, hands down and that kind of neutralizes the rest of the gameplay as a whole. It is probably what you would expect and good enough for a game that came with a magazine but I cannot see myself getting more than 2 or 3 plays out of it ever.

item.name: Guatemala Café
item.comment:
An interesting competitive puzzle game that does not show all it has to offer on a first play. The two boards make for an interesting mixture of 'game modes'. Selecting the best possible move on the available resource matrix and then placing the factories/workers/roads is quite challenging. I found that the game has a tad too many options in the beginning and a and not enough things you can do towards the end of the game.
I assume it was a first-play mishap but I won more or less through luck, that is, due to which specific bag of beans was still up for grabs to ship.
A second play could increase the rating.

item.name: Guess Who?
item.comment: Great game for kids, it is actually more difficult for them as one assumes it is. Yet, as a game for young adults or grown ups, it is not very exciting.

item.name: Haggis
item.comment: I am pretty sure everyone says that but this is essentially Tichu for 2-3 players. Why they did not make it 2-4 players is a mystery to me, but hey, so be it. An intelligent and intricate card game that is just complex enough to be challenging without being overwhelming. And it works as well with 2 as it does with more players. I know the 'theme' is pretty much plastered on but I still prefer it over Tichu's. The lovely Scottish celtic artwork on the back of the cards and the earthy colours, all good.

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: It's that one clever mechanic that makes this whole game stand out and be more entertaining that other variants of patience. However, I found the 'rules' of giving tips and helping your fellow players just too vague to prevent players from cheating (unwillingly) and therefore breaking the game. What if you accidentally say something that is a tip or cannot help but making a face before someone throws off a card etc. Good for families and non-gamers and therefore, a good choice for the SdJ, but I am afraid hardcore gamers will solve this way too quickly.

item.name: Heimlich & Co.
item.comment:
Used to play this with my Dad and brother. Pretty much a game in the style of 'identity disguise', such as Mr.Jack or 13 Dead End Drive. While the playing pieces are not very nice to look at, the board and cards are quite neat. A simple game which nicely balances random elements (dice) and bluffing.
EDIT I: The game can really become surprisingly tense during the last stretch on the score track, when it is all about preventing others from winning while making sure your guy stays close enough for the snipe victory

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment:
The game that turned me into a geek. I used to play games such as Risk, Monopoly or Trivia games before. I found this in a department store and was blown away. I played this with myself for hours and hours. I never got around playing all of the extensions and sadly, the game was destroyed in a flood (no joke). I will try and pick it up again and play it again. Compared to all those heavy games which are available today, such as Descent, HeroQuest is very simple, but this might appeal to younger people, casual gamers or gamer girlfriends. There is still a nice HeroQuest online community, with new quests, spells, monsters etc. available for download.
EDIT: Played the first three quests last night and the game is still enjoyable more due to nostalgia and novelty than gameplay. It is just too easy for the heroes to win, there is no real challenge in the quests. I think I will have to tweak this and introduce campaign rules to make this interesting again.

item.name: Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: Played this only once, very intuitve and fun game. Good Gateway game

item.name: High Society
item.comment: A classic Knizia, auctioning off cards and whoever ends with the most points wins. The crucial bit, if you are the player with the least amount of money you are eliminated, so it as bit of push-your-luck involved too. Nice filler.

item.name: High-Bid
item.comment: Nice auction and collecting game which is the more enjoyable if you play the 3M version, because the vintage feeling & theme really fits the game mechanics.

item.name: History of the Roman Empire
item.comment: Way too fiddly for my taste. Unclear rules and too much bookeeping. I enjoy history games but I feel like the theme is not very well implemented and I do not get this breeze of standing on top of the world (like in Civilization or Struggle of Empires). Not a very bad game but I feel like many other games have done it better. HX

item.name: Hoity Toity
item.comment: The game is pretty much based on one clever game play mechanic and that is simultaenous choice of action(s). Yet, I feel that something is missing from the game and the odd extra mechanic would have been nice. Sometimes, especially at the very early and the late stage of the game, the choics just seem too limited and the information regarding the other players' strategies and motives simply too easy to obtain. It also plays a tad too long for being so simplisitc. Then again, it might speed up and smoothen out with more plays

item.name: Hotel Tycoon
item.comment: A thematically more elaborate Monopoly variation. I enjoyed this game mpre than its spiritual predecessor. It is a bit more lightweight and I noticed players being less competitive when playing Hotels instead on Monopoly. The game is also a nice family game and has a better appeal to young kids due to the building pieces.

item.name: I'm the Boss!
item.comment:
Game design as simple and effective as it gets, relying purely on negotiation and communication. It reminds a bit of Dragon's Gold (which has been released later I know). The only criticism I have is that I think the colour coding, the different cards and the board could have been more efficient and less confusing when it comes to supplying the necessary information.
EDIT (5 Plays): The more I play it the less I enjoy it. I still think the premise is good and with the right people, it can be a good laugh but sometimes I feel that there is next to no control over what happens and it all depends on random card draws. I would not mind that if it was not for the possibility to eliminate players by recruiting their investors, which is always a sure fire premature loss and that is utterly frustrating for the players.
Also, I do not like the idea that you are able to divide the money (instead of shares) too, because it makes the game less cutthroat.
Had high hopes for this one but is just has not been properly thought through by Sackson.
HX

item.name: I.Q. 2000
item.comment: Decent trivia game without bells & whistles. A robust array of categories and two diffculty levels make this a nice family game.

item.name: Ice Flow
item.comment:
Ice flow does not play well with two players, there is not a lot going on and an abundance of resources everywhere for. Also, while I think you can play this game with a lot of planning ahead and cunning moves you do not have to and while this makes it a nice family game, it is the more underwhelming as a game for eurogamers. I like the bits and bobs and when reading the instructions, the game sounds somewhat exciting but it does not really come together well, at least not in a 2 player game.
HX

item.name: Imperial 2030
item.comment: I played this only once so I am not the best of judges but this did not really appeal to me. It is basically a mixture of acquire and risk, buying into countries while using the units to conquer territories. I found the game a bit dry and the rondell mechanic not very elegant, I would have rather had a classic turn order in which all players/countries resolve the same actions. This way, the game would be more tactical and less strategic. Also, it can be quite unbalanced and take too long and there is a lot of downtime should you be so unlucky and end up being Switzerland. Not a bad game but there are many similar games out there which are much better

item.name: Inca Empire
item.comment:
I only played this once so cannot really comment on replayability or how it holds up after multiple plays. I think it is a tad fiddly and I mean literally, the little road pieces and very small tokens but let's put those things aside, they do not really affect the game, albeit the gameplay.
The game is a network (rail) building system about making sure to connect to other players' networks and keeping them away from your. The road building in itself is not that exciting and only gets more tactical once the board is crowdd enough, which does not happen until the last two turns, so a missed opportunity to make something that is necessary, fun.
I like the sun card mechanic and this is what makes the game worth playing in my opinion, it is a bit strange that not all combinations are available but what the heck, just take it into consideration.
The theme is okay, a good idea and reflected in all aspects, from the artwork to the card art, but it is lacking a bit of additional flavouring.
A good game if you are into rail-games.

item.name: Infinite City
item.comment: A tile-lying game with a twist. A lot more interaction than the spiritual predecessor Carcassone, swapping tiles, swapping possession etc. The theme does not do much for me, generic sci-fi, rather bland but it works fine and kind of goes well with the idea of building a network/city. Some of the other players complained about the visuals, really small writing on the cards, no symbols to tell the buildings apart etc. No problem for me but I can see how it might turn other people off. I think a hand limit of five is too much (three would have done it) but better than drawing only one (as in Carcassonne). Great variation of the classic tile-laying game and I am looking forward to more plays. Not sure whether the high rating will hold up but we will just have to wait and see.

item.name: Invasion from Outer Space: The Martian Game
item.comment: It is hard to judge this from one play. It is definitely more complex and involved that LNOE, with an emphasis on ranged combat (death rays, ray guns, cannons etc.) which makes movement much more tactical. The theme is great, but maybe a bit too far out in order to evoke the same genre familiarity as LNOE, because the are rarely any alien movies around anymore, let alone alien movies set on a circus ground. Anyhow, the production value, balance and tongue in cheek humour is very good, like all Flying Frog games. This needs more plays with better knowledge of the rules to be fully appreciated.

item.name: Irondale
item.comment: Ouch, my heads hurts. This is an uber-complex puzzle game, about players constructing buildings (cards) from their hands and making sure that they can build them in a constellation and combination that guarantees the most points. Unfortunately, there are so many factors, concepts, abilities and last but not least combinations that this game turned out to be an exercise in AP and downtime. There are literally hundreds if not thousands of possible things to do and working out the perfect move within the given set of cards already on the table is very complicated. I think this game may appeal to a very small demographic of gamers and if the thought of pondering over a grid of numbers and symbols sounds like fun to you, this might be up your alley, alas, it is not for me. The interaction is too limited too, I would go as far as saying there is almost no interaction in the game, and that makes it even worse for me.

item.name: Isle of Skye: From Chieftain to King
item.comment: Even though I am not a big fan of players having their own playing areas (think Agricola, Puerto Rico etc.), this one works quite well and I like the randomised winning conditions. I reckon that with more plays you get more used to actually checking out the other players' "islands".

item.name: Ivanhoe
item.comment: Great trick-taking game with lots of screwing around and fun. It is a tad random and the tactical aspect is rather limited, but at least it is tangible. I like it !

item.name: JAB: Realtime Boxing
item.comment: A clever game and you can take real-time quite literally, you actually simulate the punches, blocks, haymakers but slamming the cards down on your opponents various body parts (represented by cards of course). An unusual filler, makes up what it lacks in depth with novelty for sure.

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: A very light two player game that sounds utterly confusing if someone explains it but is really simple to pick up and play, it takes a few minutes to get your head around the underlying mechanisms and strategic implications of your possible actions but once your get going, this is great fun. A tad random and I feel that sometimes you can lose even if you did not make any mistakes, but that applies to many games. I like it, but it needs more plays.

item.name: Jambo
item.comment: A bit heavier than the other Kosmos two player games. I think it is an okay game, but there is not enough possibilities to actually plan ahead, what you need to do in order to stand a chance of winning. The game is a bit too random to be deeply strategic but I suppose it makes it a better family game.

item.name: Jenga
item.comment: More a toy than a boardgame, I played Jenga in pubs a few times or as a drinking game. Great fun when the tower collapses and for kids. All in all, a good party game.

item.name: Jo Müllers Kino Quiz
item.comment: A good game for movie lovers, everyone else might find it way to difficult. The game is tailored towards true cineasts and not for those who enjoy playing Scene it?. Who is the director of Battleship Potemkin ? What was Cary Grant's real name ? Who was the third woman to win an Academy Award and so on ? My Dad and I enjoy it very much, but it is by far not a casual trivia game.

item.name: Junta: Viva el Presidente!
item.comment: I am yet to 'play' the classic Junta and I heard many good (and some bad) things about it. So when I heard they were coming out with a new version I was quite keen to try it, expecting a tweaked and improved experience of an inelegant, older game. But from what I gather (reading reviews of the old game) and my experience with the new Junta, this is way too watered down and simplified and does not got anywhere near where the old Junta ventured. I found it underwhelming but I only played it with three players so that might have been the issue. But why print it on the box if it does not play well with three ? Anyway, did not impress me at all and I have no desire to play again.

item.name: K2
item.comment: An interesting theme and the game reminds me of Ice Flow, in being a puzzle game but the interaction is really limited. If you'd take out the blocking mechanic (in the light version) the game can be played solitaire and would be completely the same. I have yet to try the hard version, but until then I cannot see myself ever really wanting to play this game.

item.name: KABOOM!
item.comment: Pretty much a game about rolling dice all the time. Not very clever or imaginative I have to say.

item.name: Ker Plunk
item.comment: Funny kids game, enjoyed this as a young lad

item.name: Key to the Kingdom
item.comment: There is a lot going on in this game, which I enjoyed as a kid, but I think the elements do not tie in well together. There is not enough content that keeps me going, as the game plays too similar each time. The artwork etc. is a bit generic, the usual fantasy stuff. The board was quite interesting as it folded out later in the game, but that neat trick enough does not balance out the weak gameplay.

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: A neat little resource management game in the vain of Bazaar and Fresco. The way the resources are distributed (through player choice instead of die roll as in Catan) makes it much more balanced than many other games. On the other hand, the asymmetrical nature of the game can result in serious disadvantages if you screw up in the beginning. Also, I found that turn order becomes more important towards the later stage of the game, so going first in the last turn is a huge advantage and there should be a downside to it, or a catch-up mechanism of some kind. The artwork is horrible though. All in all, a solid Euro that is better than Catan (albeit similar) but nothing out of the ordinary.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: This is a dice game wrapped in a zany giant monster game. There are not enough mechanics to make this strategic but the theme is great and so is the artwork. It is fun to roll the dice, they are very heavy and well designed. The game comes down to dice rolls.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: Alas, just as I thought ... this turned out to be just a simultaneous solitaire game just like Dominion. Yes, there is a hint of interactivity and some minor causal connections between oneself and the other players, but why go for less ? I want a game that is so interactive, that makes a party at Corey Haim's house look pale in comparision. Give me auctions, conflicts, backstabbing, negotiation ! ! ! This is not what i would consider a real boardgame

item.name: Kings Plate: Card Game – Series I
item.comment: An unusual card game that takes only the most basic idea behind chess (the grid system, set movement rules, check/checkmate) and turns it into an abstract game played with cards. The game comes with many different little games in once and all resemble other games, like chess or poker etc. The game is not easy to learn and the iconography and rules don't help that much. Some people might want to put themselves through that to get to the core of the gameplay in this game but most will probably just play the proper games instead. I am kind of on the fence, the general idea of making a flexible card-based game like this is okay, but I would not rush to play it.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: The simple mechanic of rolling the dice and "deploying" any subset of your dice to the board is really what this game is made of. The rest of the game is slightly below average and your run of the mill resource gathering, building and so forth. The artwork and theme are good but this game is a heavy Euro disguised as light Ameritrash. Player Interaction is limited, which would be my biggest complaint. Maybe allow players to trade, steal, switch resources / dice or else. Apart from the dice roll, no luck is involved which works fine in the game but I do prefer some luck in my games. At least, the success is not accumulative and the tide can change rather quickly, unlike in so many similar games.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: Played this in my after school club. Enjoyed the modular board and the weird creatures. As a game, it works quite well, although I never played it with actual gamers. It is a great game for kids and I wonder when someone will take the game concept and turn into an heavy game. Catan meets Heroquest maybe. It could be called Dungeon Escape and the players would have to escape the dungeon, being subjects to shifting tunnels/traps/monsters etc.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: As a kid I enjoyed it for its "action", but as a game, in terms of classic boardgame mechanics it is more or less a dexterity toy. Good for kids.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment:
Plays fast and the card system is fun. Immediate effects, countereffects and so forth. Feels like a good game of CCG sometimes.
EDIT: Played this many times with the right gruoup and the game turned out be the most balanced game I have come across since going back into boardgaming. Most games come down to the last turn(s) and it is always incredibly exciting. Especially considering this is a dicefest, that is an impressive deed. Love the theme and scenarios & flavour.

item.name: Last Will
item.comment: Another card-drafting/engine builder/solitaire game. The theme and artwork (especially the artwork) are very nice but the game does not do it for me at all. There is almost no interaction in this game and everyone is just trying to create an (negative) engine to loose all his money first. Take cards, create combos with your actions, don't mind what the others are doing and whoever gets there first is the winner. Not my cup of tea, but I don't like games without interaction in general and this is one of the best examples of a game that I would not consider a boardgame in the first place (no board, no game).

item.name: Leaping Lemmings
item.comment: A nice "racing" game, although it works quite different than other racing games. For starters, all players' lemmings move the same amount of places, so there crux lies in the tactics, pushing your luck or hiding in the bushes (which costs more movement points), always keep in mind that eagles are hovering over the lemmings heads and while players take turns in controlling them, there is always a chance of guessing which way the eagles might fly and whose lemmings they eat. The special powers (cards that are dealt our at random) add some variety to the game. Luck is limited and Leaping Lemmings is really a game of strategy and pushing your luck. The theme works great (the farther the lemmings leap over the cliff, the more VP you get). Great game, too long for a filler but excellent to start off a game day/night.

item.name: Legends of Robin Hood
item.comment: I am not sure whether this is a children's game or not. One cannot tell by the artwork I'd say. Yet the rules are so simple, I reckon it must be. Furthermore, the mechanics of the game simply do not work, period. Starting with the board (a depiction of Sherwood Forest and its surrounding areas), a third of it is useless and will never be frequented by the players, what does that tell you about the game design. Right, not playtested and polished. On top of that, the random cards players are dealt are way too random (d'oh) too make the game balance and the only strategy players can engage in is damage reduction and finding the best thing to do with a crap hand which really should not be the case. With only six cards in your hands a very limited total options in the game, there is usually only one way to go about your turn, so there is pretty much no decision making in this game whatsoever. I am not even going to start talking about the game not being true to the lore (Robin Hood is fighting against his merry men). Yuks, what a stinker !

item.name: Let's Take a Hike
item.comment: A simple push-your-luck / take-that game but the theme and artwork make it much more fun than it should be. I love how players can decide when to go on a hike and also whether they are keen to join or stay behind, interesting dynamics.

item.name: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
item.comment: I did not expect this to be quite so 'heavy', for a game based on a children's classic novel. Then again, why not challenge the brood here and then eh ? A good competitive puzzler with some limited interaction but a lovely theme and quick playing time. I am sure that some of the variants (2 player / bluffing etc.) add more spice to the stew. Kind of a galaxy trucker type puzzler without the real-time constraint.

item.name: London
item.comment: I quite enjoyed it, it was better than I expected, some player interaction in the cards and the ability to pick up the discards of other players. The element of luck involved in drawing cards makes it more enjoyable than Agricola & Puerto Rico. Still, 70 % solitaire, 30 % boardgame. Will definitely play again. The theme pushes its rating up for me, I am rather fond of London and the lovely art on the board and the cards is a bonus.

item.name: A Lone Banner
item.comment: Pretty much a deluxe version of dice rolling with some unnecessary difficulty in telling where you can attack and combos thrown in. Not my cup of tea and nothing more than the (rather conservative) sum of its parts. Way too many rules for a game that is actually extremely simple.

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment: I must admit, my friends and I play this is a heavy drinking game, with tweaked rules. It is great fun.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment:
My own vision of Tolkien's opus is way more gritty and darker than this game. That being said, I also dislike the game in here, it kind of plays itself, there is minimum strategy and too much luck, as compared to the similar competitive Beowulf.
EDIT: Played it again with a nice group and more than 2 players and enjoyed it much more. Still a bit too luck based and limited in terms of control for me. Nice theme though.

item.name: Lords of Vegas
item.comment: A very interesting mix of luck (seems appropriate in a game like this) and solid Euro mechanics. The basic ideas are area control and a little bit of planning ahead, as well as pissing off your competitors. But when it gets down to the dirty stuff, it is all about dice rolling. I can see how some aficionados of balanced gaming and non-random Euro games will get a heart attack playing this but I think this is great fun and usually, the risk pays off, especially when you are playing favourable odds, but as well know, sometimes you get lucky, sometimes you don't and that makes this game more fun than it should be. It looks gorgeous as well and all those many dice and paper money give you a bit of a Vegas feel as well. I enjoyed it a lot !

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: What a fantastic and elegant little game. My play partner told me it plays pretty much like Bridge, but I would not know, so this is probably why I am so impressed by this game. A reductionist approach to interaction but it is enough to make the decision you are taking turn by turn very important. It takes a few hands to get the hang of the right balance and I am not sure how this will hold up after dozens of plays, but for now, I am thoroughly impressed by this gem.

item.name: Louis XIV
item.comment: This game does have a handful of brilliant mechanics but unfortunately it adds a handful of more to the mix and bloats and otherwise great experience. The placement rules and trouble of getting your little cylinders back is lots of fun, simple to learn but hard to master. Yet, all the other things, the double sided tiles and especially (!) the abilities of the mission and various power tiles you need just make the game unnecessary complex and add more fiddlyness without making the game more compelling. I think this could have been a lighter but better game and as it stands it does not strike the right balance between playability and weight, because it carries a lot of excess baggage that just weighs it down.
item.conditiontext: German Edition, some text on the cards but also symbols so it is language independent.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: A great "guessing" game with enough roles to give it some complexitiy. Yet, the game is never too complex for newbies or to overstay its welcome as a filler. Lovely artwork and heart-shaped cubes too !

item.name: Lucky Loop
item.comment: A pretty simple dice rolling game that is almost too simple for my taste, apart from a very limited things you can do, there is not much decision making involved in the game and the interactivity is limited too. I will have to play this some more but it might end up on the trade pile.

item.name: Die Macher
item.comment: I have played it only once but found it to be a very good game. The theme is not for everyone and I have seen many people waving it off in sheer fear due to its "heavy" and "dry" theme. As usual, if you look behind the theme, the game is a good one, which is not as hard to learn as the legend has it but very hard to master and definitely not for those players who do not like to think ahead. In fact, the crux of the game is that you are pretty much playing four game rounds at the same time, while the first one will be resolved next and so forth. Although I am German, the theme does nothing for me (Elections ? Yawn), but it does not deduce from the fun either and I suppose it is the only theme that works with all the mechanics, knotting them together in context. The theme and lack of randomness makes this a 9 for me and the fact that it rarely sees play pushes it down to 8.5. Nevertheless, a great game indeed !

item.name: Machiavelli
item.comment:
As good as it gets when it comes to card game design which pushed the boundaries of card games. The core is the role selection and a winning condition which makes the endgame rather frenzy and tactical (who will get there first). Rounded up by a nice light fantasy theme, which is not too silly or high fantasy to put any games from the extreme spectrums off.
EDIT: I found that my sweet spot for this game is three players (just like 7 Wonders). More than four makes this less enjoyable for me

item.name: The Mad Magazine Game
item.comment: I loved this when I was a young lad, probably did not get all the jokes back then and should revisit it sometimes. The game is more a less an "anti-game" and a nice laugh, but not a game to sustain as part of a gaming group for long, more or less, an odditiy.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment:
Holy Vlaada ! What an Ameritrash beast, pre-painted miniatures, modular hex-board, scenario based, spells, artefacts, advanced skills. Great Ameritrash game with some Euro mechanics thrown in. It feels and plays great and I cannot wait to try it again, let's hope further plays prove to be even more exciting than the intro scenario.
2nd Play: Slightly underwhelmed. The game felt more or less the same and I think there is not enough randomness and excitement in here for a proper Ameritrash game. The game is balanced and Euro-like that it never feels awesome or thrilling but drags along in a stale and calculating pace. Not bad at all, but I am less impressed than I was the first time I tried it.

item.name: Magic Dance
item.comment: It pretty much comes down to being capable of remembering the movements if your witch meeples within the confusion of bizarre movement rules. If one of the players happens not to be good at it, then the game will probably be not much fun to play :-)

item.name: Magnum Sal
item.comment: An interesting Fresco variant that is more tight and unforgiving and slightly more complicated, the board setup looks interesting and is definitely unique but unfortunately plays like any other game. Generic artwork and a plastered on theme makes this more meh than yay.

item.name: Mall of Horror
item.comment: The game is far from being as vicious as I thought and it is not as much about the voting but anticipating your opponents moves and making sure the Zombies do not get you. Most of the voting in game could only go only so many ways and as such the strategic / alliance options were limited anyway. As such, I did not enjoy the game as much as I though I would and I am not very keen on the artwork which seemed a bit random and generic, would have prepared something darker and more stylized. I think the theme does not work very well, I never felt the creeping onslaught of undead like I do in Last Night on Earth for example. Not a bad game, but at its core, it is a simple placement game and more about calculation than anything else.

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment: Used to play this lots with my dad. A very simple game but loads of fun. It is competitive without being too serious and nicely balances out playing styles and playing experience. The theme is a bit to abstrace to make it one of my favourites.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: Pretty decent family game. Some people will complain about the randomness but it makes the game more animated and fun, instead of being a stale and calculated Euro. This is essentially a betting game (like a horse race) with more betting options, ships that make it to the goal, ships that don't make it, in which order etc. I did enjoy it but I felt that I had limited control about what was going on most of the time.

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment:
The number one game on my must-play (and have) list. Finally I got around to play. I say finally, yet it has only been released for a couple of weeks, but it felt like ages.
I think it is a great experience but like many other themed games, especially the similar Arkham Horror and Betrayal, I found that it depends heavily on who your are playing the game with when it comes to the question of having fun or not.
Luckily, my group was a blast and we managed to steal the victory from poor Mark who had a hard time once we discovered the sinister plan brooding in the mansion filled with maniac hairdressers.
Still, a few things that did not convince me at first play:
A. The puzzles are neat and definitely a nice detour from the common flow of Ameritrash games but I think they generate too much downtime and feel disconnected from the other part of the game.
B. The customization options are too limited
C. In general, the number of available cards in one scenario (as in equipment, events, monsters) is too limited
D. I doubt that this game is highly replayable. I think the designer managed to make it as replayabe as possible considering the storytelling nature of the game but I cannot see this holding up after more than 10 plays (without expansions), which is not my money's worth
E. The scenario felt a little bit scripted and the choices were limited, especially once the victory conditions had been discovered
Apart from that, awesome stuff

item.name: Master Labyrinth
item.comment: Light fun game with a great theme, even though it is an abstract puzzler. A tad random with four or more players but that can be part of the fun and make it even more accesible for kids. Some tactics and short term strategy pay off as well as a knack for visual thinking. All in all, a great filler but might frustrate Euro veterans due to the chaos.

item.name: Mastermind
item.comment: Despite the hype, I never found this game amazing, because the player interaction is not very intense. Once the "mastermind" put down the code, all you do is find out by trial and error, which could pretty much be done by a computer as well. No strategy, tactic, bluffing and so forth. More or less a puzzle game.

item.name: Masters Gallery
item.comment: Good game ! Not sure what the best strategy in the game is and how much there is to it, but it feels different to other games and that is good enough.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment:
Memoir '44 might as well be the best gateway game for wargaming out there. Command cards (unit activation), terrain, scenarios, line of sight etc. many elements of classic wargaming are in there. And yet, the game is just as simple as most Days of Wonder games, if not simpler and it is still tremendous fun. Being a 2-player game, the basic gameplay is very much like an extended (in variety, not in complexity of course) version of chess, take turns in moving your units, fire away and hope for the best. I think the game can appeal to a wide range of gamers (excluding the unnecessarily serious) because of the luck element. To me, it makes the game more dynamic and fun, will I be going to draw the right cards, roll the symbols I need etc. All this and the fact that there are myriads of expansions out there make this an absolute winner.
EDIT: Having played this a few times in a row recently, I still love but sometimes long for something similar of slightly higher complexity (i.e C&C Ancients or Combat Commander) - Maybe I just need an expansion ?

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: Played it only once and got smashed by the experience player. I am not a big fan of games that have a handful of make n break strategies that will instantly kill everyone else. This feels good but looks atrocious, I have a hard time telling the districts apart etc. Also, the goals are too varied in difficulty, some are just much harder too achieve while not being worth the extra VP at the same time. I found this too be a tad too brainburny but maybe more plays will loosen this up a bit

item.name: Middle-Earth Quest
item.comment: Middle Earth Quest really felt like a mixture of Arkham Horror and Fury of Dracula. Take the clue system and call them favours, the encounters and permanent "plots" in play and you have the same race against time and roam around the board feeling as in Arkham Horror. The combat system and hidden monsters popping up all over the board work just like in Fury of Dracula. The game still works and I must admit that despite a weenie lack of innovation it is probably the best that could have been done with a adventure / Ameritrash game set in Middle-Earth. The played cooperation is limited and we rarely discussed tactics as there was usually an obvious choice. While the game is far less random than other adventure games, it feels a bit more non-dynamic and stale. The events and encounters are never crucially intervening, so aren't the counselors or minions. The endgame in a draw is also oddly anticlimactic, which may very well be most crucial points of my criticism. Of course, as you might expect by a FFG Lord of the Rings game, the artwork, theme, flavour text and so forth is amazing and very enjoyable. As for now, I do prefer other adventure games (Arkham Horror / Fury of Dracula / Descent) but I am sure I have not seen the last of MEQ.

item.name: Mille Bornes
item.comment: Loved this as a kid, very simple but fun. Not a lot of strategy involved, more or less experience in the game and lots of luck. Still, great for kids, my nice loves this.

item.name: Mississippi Queen
item.comment: Deceptively simple, but intricate and delicate in its design. A good, programming & racing game for 4-5 players.

item.name: Monad
item.comment: Monad is quite the brainburner and there is some luck involved but for the most part it is about planning and putzzling your way to the top. It is more complex than most light to medium card games.

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment: Despite the massive hype, I never enjoyed Monopoly. I found the "theme" of finance very uninteresting and never enjoyed being a money shark. People take this game way too serious and it is no fun.The runaway leader problem is just too severe to make this a family game.

item.name: Monopoly Deal Card Game
item.comment: A vicious and chaotic take-that style of card game that is more or less an exercise a retaliative chaos with a popular them woven around it. Apart from some limited push-your-luck, I don't see much game in here, but it is silly fun nonetheless.

item.name: Monster Mash
item.comment: A funny toy, which I enjoyed very much as a kid, smashing about in my room, demolishing the furniture while splashing the monsters.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: Very simple gameplay and premise but it works very well. I am impressed by the playtesting because when we played the game, many different situations came up but the mechanics always held up. The theme is a bit goofy but I do not mind.

item.name: Mr. Pop!
item.comment: Used to love this as a kid, a nice mix of toy and game. The random element makes it great fun and not too competitive,

item.name: Mr. Ree!: The Fireside Detective
item.comment: Found the theme of this game a bit more appealing than Clue, although I only played it a few times. Unfortunately, you need three or more players to play this game, a thing I do not like in games. A nice, rather unknown alternative to clue.

item.name: Murder! Mystery! Mastermind!
item.comment: Another game that tries to finally make a deduction game that simulates a murder mystery properly. Did it succeed? Well, it does away with the note taking and adds much more game to the game, but it it will probably still appeal only to people who are inclined to play deduction games in the first place, others (especially lighter gamers) might be put off by the complexity, playing time and difficulty to formulate a strategy.

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment: To me, the best thing about this game is the theme. I adore the Name of the Rose and this is probalaby as close as you can get to playing a mystery game set in an abbey (apart from the game The Name of the Rose itself of course). But I still think it is only medicore and although it is refreshingly different from your average Euro game (not much different from Cluedo though), there is not enough to it too make it deeply engaging for me. Yes, the way you ask questions and take notes makes a big difference but it is not something I derive joy from while playing. The event cards are interesting and prevent the game from becoming stale, especially with multiple plays. I will have to play it a few more times to see where the rating might go.

item.name: Navegador
item.comment:
Not very keen on the 'theme' but the map looks gorgeous. Our game apparently was very unusual and it refused to end, although the excitemnt had been long (long!) gone already. One thing I don't like about the game is that there is not set limit of turns in the game, so that decision become more meanigful. Sometimes, people just keep going on and on and on, not ending the game and doing the same stuff over and over, hoping to catch up and that is just dull as I don't feel any progress or dynamic process is still going on in the game once everything is explored and players have settled for a tactic. So, to me, this is a failed design, but that is just me and I can see how some might like it. I am astonished about the lack of chance and randomness in the 'game' and people who know me are aware of the fact that a game without chance, is not in game in my definiton.
Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: I am not a big fan of sci-fi settings in general, be it in movies, books or games. There are no many sci-fi films I like and those I do like are masterpieces and there cannot be an argument regarding their quality really (Alien, 2001, Star Wars etc.). When it comes to games, the same applies. Neuroshima Hex bears a post-apocalyptic sci-fi / mad max earth setting and despite the good execution and love for detail in creating the theme kit does not do anything for me. The game however is great and I like the mixture of puzzling and drawing luck, because a game without random mechanics usually does not appeal. The different "races" or "factions" are diverse enough to make the game interesting over a long course of time, however, I found that those differences, while they are definitely in place, are not that evident and apparent during gameplay which is a shame because it would have been nice for those subtle difference to have a bigger, observable impact on the game.

item.name: The New Dungeon!
item.comment: Very simple dungeon crawler and similar to Talisman. Less chaotic but also less interesting in my opinion. Roll and Move, that is all there is to it and some push your luck.

item.name: New World: A Carcassonne Game
item.comment: Like so many, maybe all Carcassonne-clones, this is a good game, but I cannot see myself ever choosing this game over the original and as such, there is not real point to keep this in my collection. The artwork and theme is nice but that does not make it better or even equal to the original game.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: An interesting take on the 'Risk' genre. It's not about defending but clever timing of attacks and managing your troops and money at the same time. The game almost feels like boardgame with some take-that gameplay. However, despite the fact that it looks very tactical and intricate, it does sport a very high degree of randomness, many die rolls and random card powers. The game is short and light-hearted enough that I don't mind, but it is definitely more at home in the Ameritrash-division than Euro and I might not always be up for so much randomness in my games as the lack of control is really more apparent than in many other games that are similar. The bits and pieces are very nice, it's a shame that the cards and tiles are ugly, kind of cancels the nice miniatures to a degree. A good game, not for everyone.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: A very focused and simple card game, all about push your luck and looking our for your opponents' cards.

item.name: Nobody is Perfect
item.comment: The simple idea of "inventing" your own answers to crazy questions is everything that makes the game work. The mechanics do not really matter and are not very sophisticated anyway. The game is fun with the right people.

item.name: Nobody is Perfect
item.comment: Great fun with the right people

item.name: Nostra City
item.comment: Neat bluffing/backstabbing game about mobsters trying to bail out their boss while fighting for survival and the upper hand in the ranks. Played with people in the right mind set, this can be a hilarious blast, negotiations and threats. The game itself is okay and well balanced, considering the randomness. Not sure how replayable the game actually is, but apart from that, a neat game with a good theme.

item.name: Noteability
item.comment: Good game. A music quiz with one player playing the tunes on the piano. Most of the tunes are oldies, evergreens or theme tunes. Still, the average person will drown and you can play this with music geeks only.

item.name: Nox
item.comment: Very nice little card game, can be vindictive but still has limited tactics too it (and some luck of the draw). Best played over a couple of rounds and with opponents of the same strength.

item.name: Octrix
item.comment: It may not look like much, especially if you happen to play with the 3M version ( not sure if there is any other version anyway) but there is a neat game in here. Trick taking with some bluffing and risk involved. Basically, it is a trick taking game with all cards held known by the other players at any point during the game, the question is however, when to play which card, anticipating and your opponents' moves.

item.name: Olympos
item.comment: Only played it once an we (not we but the rules explainer) got half the rules wrong or forget about them, so playing this felt like holding on to water with your bare hands. Anyhow, I liked the overall structure but I felt that there is not much there but the sum of its parts. Neat Euro mechanics with resource collection, a bit of area control, but again, not enough interaction to make it interesting. Taking over enemy territory is just as expensive for you as it is for the victim (most of the time) so it feels more or less like a bargain than warfare. The endgame feels a bit obscure, is it triggered, is it not triggeres. But hey, there is BOOBS in the game, amazing.

item.name: Omega Centauri
item.comment:
Had the pleasure of being taught by the designer himself. I really did not like Twilight Imperium that much and was worried because some are in the habit of comparing these two games. But I was pleasantly surprised and can now say that I prefer this one by a mile. It is dense and very easy to learn but hard to master (we only played the Introduction game) and there are many decisions to be made. Some of which might be too obvious in the beginning but that may be just the case in the beginner game. You usually have on less action than you need and that is the hallmark of a nice design. I like the multiple paths to victory (points) and I managed to do fine just by building so many monuments early in the game and refrain from a warfaring strategy (also because I stood no chance against Nigel anyway).
I would love to try to advanced game because of the various alien races, the secret action selection and new sector types.
I can only second Paul's outrage, why is this not getting published ?

item.name: On the Underground
item.comment: Is this similar to Ticket to Ride ? I don't know, but this one is fun, way simpler than it looks, although it takes a good hour to figure out the distances between the stations and other finer details of the gameboard (/w pieces). A basic track-laying game it is refreshingly unlayered. No player hands or event cards etc. Personally, I would prefer a bit more random elements, some events, the chance to be nasty with your fellow players (track breakdowns, power failures etc.), but I suppose that wuld throw the Euro-Appeal. London is always a nice theme (Hometown, Baby!), so that is a plus for me.

item.name: Opera
item.comment: A nice strategy/economy game with an unsual theme. Instead of goods or stocks, people buy pieces of music and raise or lower the worth (fame) of composers. The best thing about Opera is the budget system which determines the turn order and thus the roles played by each player. While this might look like a small part of the game it is essentially the heart of the game and what makes it stand out from the crowd. For my taste, the game requires too much planning ahead and once you are behind there is a slim chance you can catch up. It is purely skill/strategy based. A few more luck/random factors could have done the game good. Still, the theme and interesting turn order resolution make this a one worth checking out.

item.name: Operation
item.comment: More a game than a toy, the novelty quickly wears off. A fun game for the children, although it can be quite hard for them and frustrating.

item.name: Orient Express
item.comment: I do much prefer 'case' based games in deduction games than games where you pretty much have to hunt down a random bit of information that is missing from the game by finding all the others (Clue, Mystery of the Abbey, Mystery Express etc.). One of my favourites is 221b Baker Street and Orient Express definitely looks like a step up from that. I have played two cases and I found the cases to be a bit tedious and dull and more about numbers than creative thinking. I prefer cases in which the mystery lies behind a seemingly inexplicable crime scene instead of who sat for dinner with whom for who long. I have always been more fond of Conan Doyle than Christie so that is probably why. Anyhow, the game is okay, but I cannot say I enjoyed it a lot when I played it due to the nature of the cases.

item.name: Origo
item.comment: A simple version of the basic Civilization premise. Players will populate, move around and fight within Europe in order to score points for establishing countries and having the majorities in the regions, on sea and in general. The game is an area-control game at its core, slightly spiced up by the (slighlty rough) combat mechanics and card system. The theme is not bad, although it does only hold up for about 20 minutes. The game is a tad underwhelming with three players and people who played it before will usually annihilate others. Once you are behind, there is little you can do to go for the top spot again which is something I never like in games. The endstage of the game might be a bit too confusing for some, I know it was for me, with the overloaded board too many countries and tokens to keep track of. Still, I would play this game again, especially with the right people.

item.name: Otto's großes Ottifanten-Spiel
item.comment: Soloed it as a kid, cannot remember much. I was into the quirkyness.

item.name: Outburst!
item.comment: A good trivia game that relies more on everyday knowledge than complex trivia. Good family game. The limited time element makes it exciting

item.name: Palastgeflüster
item.comment: A decent card game with one interesting and unusual mechanic and that is that the colour of the card you play determines who takes the next turn, which has an unique but quite tactical feel to it. The special powers of the characters remind of of Citadels, which is not a bad thing. It is a bit unfortunate that the game is in German and despite featuring English writings on the reference sheets, it takes a while to get used to it. Furthermore, I a have yet to find out how strategic or luck based this game actually is, but for now, it is a solid filler and I suspect there is potential for the rating to increase with more plays.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Bought the game at Leisure Games. The mechanics and flow of the game are well thought out.Unfortunately, I had to rate this down because after playing it with different groups, I must admit that this heavily relies on the right people. Pandemic is very cooperative and there are not many mechanic-related interactions available, so all the discussing, negotiation, planning etc. is voluntary and if people don't go for it, the game feels pointless. I had players sitting around not "getting" the game because they refused to interact with other players, which renders your own options useless. Still, with the right people, good game.

item.name: Panic Station
item.comment: God knows I do love my traitor games and while this is not the innovative and revolutionary game some people thought it might be, it is a solid entry in the genre. The rules are terrible, counter-intuitive and have not been proofread, but the gameplay is still good and fun so don't let that deter you and look our for some good reference sheets and rules on the geek. Only played this once so cannot really say how much is strategy and how much is just randomness and luck, I felt there was a lack of control over some elements but maybe that is just because I never played it before. Good one.

item.name: Pantheon
item.comment:
A very good, medium-heavy Euro. I do like the theme, although it is not implemented to a degree I would have prepared it to be. The idea that the players are not playing one civilization each, but rather control the same civilization together, trying to score VPs is intriguing and reminds me of Britannia. Unfortunately, apart from different starting positions and one unique event, all the cultures are the same and I would have wished for more variety, different gods and more historical tie-ins.
I found that there are a lot of things you can do wrong in this game. Things that can effectively cripple you. When you build too many columns too soon, run out of cards or end up with a bad god combo, you are out of luck.
The column scoring does not make sense to me either, why give someone who is already reeking in more points due to having the most columns give the multiplier too ? This created a runaway leader in our game and I am not sure why that is necessary
That being said, all those games do not change the fact that the game is good fun.

item.name: Parade
item.comment: A clever little game with a weird plastered on theme. But once you got behind all the witty comments about the theme, a neat tactical card game lies behind it with plenty opportunities to backstab and annoy other players.

item.name: Pay Day
item.comment: Enjoyed this as a kind, all the money and the goofy theme. As a game, it is all over the place, not very good.

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment: More of the same but very well executed civilization building game. Build tiles, lay them onto your playing field, gather resources, continue from step 1 for 9 nine rounds. Works very nice and the bidding mechanic is neat because once you bid you cannot increase the bid, only change where it goes, quite ingenious I might say. Good balance and the disasters add more flavour, so do the sea tiles from the expansion. I found the building rules (you can use them even if unbuild) very confusing and I think they should have changed that during playtesting. One of my favourite Euros (after 1 play that is)

item.name: The Perfect 10
item.comment: An interesting hybrid of Mastermind and your usual quiz games. It is interesting for trivia buffs, but it does lack the communication to make it a really good game and it also works only with 2 or 4 players IMHO, more is just too much. Getting closer to the answers sometimes just ends up in a long run of trial and error which is not really what this game is (or should be) about but what can you do. Still, should be high on the list for couples that happen to be fans of trivia games.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: I do prefer RA over Phoenicia. I found the game a bit too fiddly and the theme way too inconsistent, the player interaction is not as tight as in other auction games I have player. Furthermore, the advantage of the leading player(s) is heavily unbalanced and however goes first controls the auction, has the most money and so forth. Also, I found the game tends to become interesting only in the last two rounds. I would play it again, but it is just more of the same with a weak theme and not enough polish.

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment: Played this a few times now. Simple push-your-luck game a a nice filler that plays best with 2 or 3. Good fun if played with people who are into it.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Builders Duel
item.comment: I do like this game and the card-grid action selection system but I am terribly annoyed by the starting player mechanic, not only because I was on the receiving end of the crapstick, but I just made a game that should be all about subtle and fine decisions way to imbalanced. The contested cards should be decided by a Euro-mechanic, such as secret bidding and not through sheer chance and luck. That can be very frustrating for both players because even If I would win the game, I'd rather not win it by chance and disadvantages on the side of my opponent. The theme is neat, but more or less just an excuse for sophisticated artwork which is fair and square in my book and If you like World Without End (or Pillars of the Earth) you will enjoy this game. Not as deep and engaging as its namesakes but then again, it plays quicker and is easy to carry.

item.name: Pingu-Party
item.comment: Cute little game, which was actually very exciting and all our (quite serious Euro) Gamers were surprised by the tension caused by this game. Some rules polish and variants, especially regarding the scoring and end of rounds would do the game good. Great for kids, families, fillers, gateway games.

item.name: PIX
item.comment: A neat party game that uses the classic formula of draw-to-guess but limits your creativity by forcing you to use pixels on a magnetic board instead of pens or clay etc. While this may sound as same-old same-old, it actually works quite well because coming up with pixelated representations of thinks like "Wolf" ain't as easy as it sounds. The idea of rewarding the players that use less pixels than others is also quite clever. Good laugh !

item.name: Pizza Box Football
item.comment: Only played the first two difficulty settings so far but love the game. Captures the spirit and feeling of Football without being overbearing of unnecessary dry and complicated.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment:
Planet Steam This game: All plays | User plays It is ironic how I have been known to complain about the lack of theme and fancy schmonsens in eurogames and here comes a game that sports a wagon car full of bits, a board the size of a small country and so much theme and artwork, it feels almost like an Ameritrash game.
But the core game mechanic is the market and the placement rules and the co-relation between production and selling of goods.
That being said, in this case, I am not sure all the bling and theme add much too the came and make the more interesting than it actually is. Sure, farming steam on a remote planet is exciting but most of it comes down to number crunching after all, no matter how creepy that worker looks or how futuristic the 'tank' might have been designed.
I feel like the designers went all out on making this a lavish production but this reminds me of the idiom that more is not necessarily better and in this case, I would have prefered a slimmed down and minimalist version of the same game.
The market is an interesting idea and remindes me of an old 3M game, Executive decision but it comes with a lot of baggage of which 70 % is just that.
Not a bad game but I feel it does not live up to its reputation of being an holy grail game and I have played much shorter and simpler games that still have a better flow and more rewarding gameplay.

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment: From a glimpse of the board, one can tell that Portobello Market's prototype used to be a traingame. It looks exactly like the Ticket to Ride board. That being said, I never played Ticket to Ride and as such, Portobello Road has a lot to offer to me. A solid Euro and light brain teaser, with only very limited luck. The theme is lovely and so are the pieces. The two player game is more of a brain teaser, more focused and tight while playing with more players, especially four becomes more frantic and chaotic, in a good way. Still, the game is missing the big WOW factor and while being a solid and entertaining game, it will probably not see much play to many better games being around.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: An okay game, I found it way too long, especially towards the end when it comes down to number crunching and you pretty much loose touch with what is going on around you, at least I did. I does not help that the theme ins painfully dull and boring. Still, one of the better Euros out there. I cannot help but think that the game will play pretty similar every time as the natural balance of progression in this game is pretty linear and you will never have many tactical options and usually one obvious strategy to go for in each round and that is something I find rather uninteresting.

item.name: Power Struggle
item.comment: Many people despise me for that philosophy but happily state it again. I like my euros simple and my ameritrash complex. This falls right into the wrong puddle of mud. Way too complex and dry for my taste. There is also not enough interaction. I am not saying there is none, but the game did not facilitate the kind of discussions and planning or banter I would expect from game that attempts to emulate the ongoings in a company like this. Id rather struggle with decisions because the strategic implications are hard to figure out instead of the mechanics itself. Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Powerboats
item.comment: Okay racing game. The idea of accelerating (or decelerating) by adding/removing dice which can be rolled in turn is a nice blend of luck and strategy, but it is still too random for me and just takes too long for what it is.

item.name: Privacy 2
item.comment: The basic idea is not band, although it is more or less a common partygame more or less (" I never had " ). The problem is that 75 percent of the questions are boring (I once rode a train without a ticket, weeeee) and usually, the players in our group start coming up with (dirty) questions of their own at some point, so, might as well just use some pens & paper to play this

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: Although I am not a big fan of generic fantasy settings, I enjoy the gameplay and the mechanics. I only played this game Solitaire,

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Just another bland and generic efficiency engine games about producing goods and all the other stuff that is utterly boring. Multi-Solitaire and contradictory to my idea of what defines a boardgame in the first place.

item.name: Puzzle Strike
item.comment: I am not a big fan of Dominion, because it is really a solitaire game played by multiple players at once. Puzzle Strike tries to cash in on the hype and create a hybrid of a flash-game (think Puzzle Quest / Tetris) and Dominion. It might appeal to you if you are into Dominion and are looking for something new and slightly (only slightly) different, but if you, like, loath Dominion then this is not for you.

item.name: Queen's Ransom
item.comment: Is this a game ? Not sure, it is more less memory with a twist, all you have to do memorize the cards and try to avoid your opponents from doing the same. Might be good for families and non-gamers.

item.name: Quinto
item.comment: A neat brain burner that feels like Scrabble with number crunching ( and without the letters obvs). Dont play this with AP candidates as this will devestate all the slow burning candles in yer living room. Some luck, but the bulk of the action comes down to quick calculation, a good eye and concentration !

item.name: Quo Vadis?
item.comment: Not my kind of game. Too simply negotiations without enough factors to make it interesting. And screwing people over like that is just not something I enjoy

item.name: Ra
item.comment: Good Auction game with enough mechanics to make the game not purely skill/strategy based, so it can be played with a good mix of players. The theme (like in all Knizia games) is very generic and does not add or take anything to the experience. Played it with a particular nice group who were very into it, must try it with other groups as well and see how it plays.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: The prospect of yet another "deck"-builder game had me grinding my teeth. I hate Dominion with a passion and the similarities seemed rather obvious, but here I am, admitting that I did enjoy RFTG after all. Of course, like Dominion, it lacks the player interaction of so many games which came out recently (Dominion, Dungeon Lords) and is more or less a mulit-solitaire game. In a 2-player game, it is quite fun to see what your opponent is up to, but am really doubtful whether I will be able and willing to follow the respective progresses of four players at all. The artwork is great so is the flexibility of the deck.

item.name: Rage
item.comment: Played this as an alternative to other mainstream card games such as Uno. Enjoyed it a bit more than the former. A good family game, but not one of my favourites.

item.name: Ready! Set! Spaghetti!
item.comment: Played this as a young lad. Not much of a game because you cannot really change the outcome of the game, it is sheer luck and more a toy than a boardgame. It is fun nonetheless, takes a while to set up though. Good for kids.

item.name: The Real Ghostbusters Game
item.comment: One of my favourite games as a kid, I spent hours letting the ghostbusters roam around the board, chasing ghosts and trying not to die. The theme and artwork is very appealing for kids and young lads. Enjoyed it very much.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: An intriguing game which has quite a lot of visual appeal despite the thin theme. The game play is a tad dry unpolished (The reference sheet has an "Action 8" which is "not to take an action"), but becomes more intriguing as you go along. I found a bit too much going on for my taste and it is real feat of concentration to keep track of all the factors that are playing into the final score, lots of mental bookkeeping, which is not a bad thing if that is what you are into, but it is easy to loose track and trail behind if you do not pay attention all the time. I understand that this is the whole point of the game but my point is that it might not be for everyone and it feels like a competitive puzzle/sandbox game with all of the dynamics being the other players (mostly). Still, a good game and if played within a group of balanced playing strength it is quiet satisfying.

item.name: Regatta
item.comment: My Dad and I used to play this. A nice theme, not your usual horse race, although the board can be quite confusing in the beginning (Where is the race track). Still, a nice game and another solid entry from 3M.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment:
Just to get it out of the way, while this shares the same basic premise as the core game of BSG, I think there is no way this delivers the same experience as BSG. The decisions in The Resistance are not as intricate and delicate and sometimes, even though you are a human, you will still struggle to make the 'right' decision, which adds nicely to the overall atmosphere of paranoia. The Resistance resembles the bare-bone calculation of BSG's skill checks and the traitor discussions which result thereof but in terms of depth, atmosphere and intensity, this cannot compete with the grand daddy of all traitor games. Still, a neat little game.
EDIT: Only good without the plot cards and with 5 or 6 players, not more.
EDIT2: I still like this game because of the meta-game but I feel that it is just too hard (too random) to spot the spies, unlike BSG where you have lots (lots!) of time and occurrences that promote the exposure of the traitors. Most of the time, the spies won the game just out of pure chance (4 people on a mission with 6 players, how can you exclude the two spies unless you know exactly who they are ? Not gonna happen)

item.name: Rheinländer
item.comment: An interesting area control game. It could do with a longer playing time as we just started to get going with all the mergers of Duchies and such but maybe they tried to keep the confrontational level down. Now that I played it once I want to try it again and improve my strategy which is the hallmark of a good game, makes me want to come back. The board is not the easiest to make out but then again, at least they did not make it too abstract. Like the 'theme', that is, the setting (I used to live next to the Rhine). Another solid Knizia.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: What I like about this game is that the randomness and luck factor is immense, yet it is still caused by tangible elements which are the other players. So whatever happens and no matter how much chaos is caused, it is not down to that untouchable mechanic but what the other programmers do. Thus, the randomness does not feel frustrating but rewarding if anything. On the other hand, I did struggle with the complex map a bit and while I do not mind being annihilated and outsmarted by oppenents, I found it a bit annoying that I had so many oversights and lapses. Of course, I see how this is the point of being a good gamer, but it feels to brainy and puzzle-like for me. Still a nice one.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: It sure looks pretty but for that price, all you get is a very sophisticated Yahtzee clone (albeit better than King of Tokyo). The interaction is limited and there is not much you can do to hinder, let alone attack opponents. Sure, some of you dice rolls might result in minus points for your opponents, but the problem is that you would never make a strategic decision to do so but rather accept that fact if you should happen to roll the dice that cause minus points for you enemies and as such, it is as random as the rest of the game. At least, there are two levels of strategy, push-your-luck when rolling the dice and some decision make as to where to allocate the workers/money. An okay Yahtzee clone that is not interactive enough to make it shine.

item.name: Royal Palace
item.comment: Cannot say I liked this one. A very try and bland worker placement game and pretty much a blend of Louis XIV and Fresco, two great contenders for the JASE-Award of the year. The game is not broken or horrible, it is just uninspired and boring, not enough interaction and the theme does not work for me (whatever there is left of it).

item.name: Rumble in the House
item.comment: A super-light but surprisingly fun little filler game that is not as superficial as it looks (and sounds) on first glance. Great if you have 5 minutes to fill and want to play something that is both chaotic and random but gives players choices to make still.

item.name: Ruthenia
item.comment: Designer Denys Lonshakov brought the prototype of his game Ruthenia. Although it is not my type of game, I though it was not bad, alas not innovative enough to stand out from similar games. Factions in Eastern Europe battle it out for territories and the respective victory points. The flow of the game is pretty traditional, move units, buy units, build improvements (markets, forts, ships etc.) and go to war. The battles are resolved via cards representing units, with actual formations and extra event cards played on top of it. Unfortunately, I found that the "fighting" is not as much fun as it is time consuming and I'd rather play a game which emulates the tension of a battle instead of simulating the process.
