Still, with a 90 minute playing time, some randomness (rebel uprisings, free factions etc.) and the ability to backstab a bit will probably appeal to genre enthusiasts.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: I admit, I am a bit spoiled when it comes to games involving a traitor, as I had the pleasure of being introduced to the mechanic through the brillian BSG. However, the prospect of a light filler/opener game including a traitor (Saboteur) intrigued me. The game plays simple and fast, as expected but the traitor mechanic is not very slick. Being the traitor and staying undetected is almost impossible and the "suspence" and "accusing" usually stops after a few turns, once it is settled who the traitor is, what follows is just a game of luck, because however holds the right cards, wins, all tactics and strategy is pretty much thrown overboard ( not that there was awfully much in the first place, but at least the traitor is thinking about how to remain undiscovered). We had fun, but it must be said that my gamegroup us very lively and as such we threw around quite a few accusations, but with the "wrong" kind of people, the gameplay can be rather stale. Again, a nice filler which is good in the face of a lacking alternative, but other than that, the novelty wears flat rather quickly.

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment:
Now I see where 7 Wonders took half of its inspiration from. A very basic and streamlined Card-Euro / Efficiency engine game with a terrible theme and artwork. It does not play very elegant and will probably be solved after half a dozen plays, there is just not enough variety in the cards to make this epic or engaging enough. And being a simple game like that, there is just not enough excitement, speed or luck in the game.
EDIT: Played it again, and it's not all that bad just outdated and ugly as hell.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: Amazing components, great gameplay and quick as well. There is almost nothing wrong with this game apart from the fact that it is more or less an abstract with no theme and that is a shame really, apart from that, big hit.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: Like I said on a hundred other occasions before, I am not a fan, that is, I dislike efficiency engine games, especially if they lack any or much player interaction (I like Kingsburg!). San Juan is another example of everybody doing his own things, just like in Dominion or RFTG. Very limited interaction and usually, at one point, players lose track and interest in what the others are building. Another multi-solitaire game, unninovative and bland. HX

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: Like my fellow player said, the board may not look like much bit this is a very neat a good game. This is the perfect example why I prefer uni-board games to multi-solitaire games. Despite being galaxies simpler than Agricola or Puerto Rico, this game is much more interactive and clever, forcing the players to consider their opponents moves and eventually bribing them to help them out. Very simple, very clever. HX

item.name: Say Anything
item.comment: Almost as funny and interesting as party games yet. This is more of a get-to-know / partygame that is good for groups of friends and schools etc. (or maybe even dates) but it is great fun and creates a hilarious atmosphere when played with the right people who are into it and have the right sense of humour. Not much of a game in here in terms of mechanic but a simple idea that brings people together around a table and makes them laugh with each other.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: A basic variant of the hidden identity game, such as Mr.Jack or Fury of Dracula. The mechanics are deceptively simple, but the game does faciliate a lot of communication between the players and that is what makes the game fun, that is, only if you play with the right people of course. That being sad, playing Mr.X is much harder than it seems.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment:
What to say about Scrabble ? I enjoy playing it with people that enjoy words and reading, unfortunately, those are rare.
EDIT: Played it again and I do not understand why people are so wary when it comes to playing Scrabble. I think they are afraid that people think they are stupid if they lose etc. I do not really mind, I am not English anyway so I have a natural disadvantage here. I still like it, I like the pace and playing with words.

item.name: SET
item.comment: An unusual little game, that is actually more of a brain exercise. It is quite interesting but I would not go as far as calling it fun really and there is not a lot of game in there neither. I would have preferred some more hands-on mechanics, turns, time limits, etc., instead of a free-for-all shouting out kind of thing, which might excite some people but it just stresses me out. Also, being good as this game is mostly a question of repetition and pattern recognition and if you cannot afford to have lot of the former and suck at the latter, you are doomed.

item.name: Sewer Pirats
item.comment: The surprise hit of Essen for me and I think some others in my gaming group too. This game is lots of fun, has interesting decisions for you to make without ever feeling to fiddly or AP-prone. The theme is brilliant and generates lots of laughs. Another plus is the playing time,you can fit in 2 or 3 games in 90 minutes which is great. Also like the advanced rules, random teams or team auctions.

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: Quite an intriguing premise (although the artwork is horrible) but I feel that most of the game is just too random and there are not a lot of decisions to be made. The dice rolling dictates where you have to go most of the time and depending on what you get (or don't), you can try to find out who is on your side (or not). Once that is done, the rest is just dice rolling and hoping for the best. The theme is okay, but like so many Japanese/Asian-flavoured fantasy games, just a butchered copy of Western mythology paired with cutie pies. There are much better traitor games out there, and much better games in general.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment:
Awesome cooperative/traitor game. I love the theme and I think it works well with the game. There is no downtime, considering this plays with up t 8 players. I am yet to play the expansion and reckon this might climb up to a 10. One thing I am not sure of is to what extent the traitor can do stuff to influence the game apart from remaining hidden, as compared to BSG for example. There is always one more thing to do than you can and the game is both exciting and tense. I like it.
EDIT: Played it four times in a short time now and while I still think this does not deserve to sit in the back of gamers' shelves just because of BSG, it does not hold up all too well after multiple plays within a short period of time. The traitor's options are too limited and so are the knights, in my opinion. Also, the game is too easy to win (Yes, I would like to try the expansion).

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company
item.comment: This adds some interesting stuff without changing the game completely or making it too heavy and complex for newbies. The Merlin/Travel mechanic is neat and so are the extra white cards. I will probably never (or rarely) play it with seven or eight players of I am not sure the 2nd traitor card will ever see the light of day, unless you play the hard variant with 2 (possible) traitors in a 5/6 player game. More of the same, solid, if not ingenious, expansion.

item.name: Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective
item.comment: A very interesting 'game' concept to which the word game can only be applied on a very loose basis. It is more of a collaborative narrative whodunnit experience with lots of clues and deducing. I think it is the most fun if played cooperatively and pondering about who the culprit might be. Sometimes the clue matrix does not really work and there are no clues where there should be clues (in my opinion) and i would not have minded a few more red herrings for good measure, just to make the city of London feel more dynamic and alive with people bustling all over the place. Anyway, interesting game and one of the rare occasions where the theme is perfectly captured in a game.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: There is just too much randomness in this game to make it interesting, it is more or less an awareness game than about planning ahead and strategy. You might call it slightly tactical at best, but due to the constant change of your pieces movement range, you have to adapt your plan each turn. It is like chess on speed but not as much fun as it sounds because people will quickly just go from planning and pondering to hoping for the best. Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: Amazing mix of wargame (risk like) and Euro mechanics (Cube FTW). I think this really left me speechless and I want to play it again. Fantastic theme.

item.name: Die Siedler von Catan
item.comment: Interesting game which I played for the first time recently as many non-casual gamers fear it like the vampire fears the cross, I am not sure why. The game and the fun you have while playing it depends on who you are playing it with, some people enjoy the fierce competition and trying to blockade each other, refuse trading etc., others may find it too vicious. The random element is a nice idea, also experienced players have a big advantage. Another flaw in my opinion is the accumulative nature of successes, the more resources you have, the more you can build and the more you build the more resources you have, which can be a pain in the ass should the starting conditions be unbalanced because that will be hard to flatten out later in the game. Still, a neat little game which could have done with some better artwork and theme instead of the plaster-on. I reckon that the expansions add a lot to it but I am not sure whether Ill ever be able to give those a go, considering the general reluctance of geeks to play it.

item.name: Simon
item.comment: More a toy than a game, Simon is a fun memory game. The novelty quickly wears off and I guess nowadays it is more a collectible item for 80ies nostalgists.

item.name: Skip-Bo
item.comment: A simple card game which is more luck-driven than anything else. The best thing to do is to avoid mistakes but apart from that there is not much strategy involved, maybe blocking other players to some extent but that is about it. Not bad for ten minutes but becomes boring and stale very quickly.

item.name: Skull King
item.comment: A great trick taking game in the Style of Wizard. A jolly god theme. Learning the strategy and which card takes which might take a few plays, but that is no bother.

item.name: Slapshot
item.comment: I think the basic idea behind this is good. The drafting and then the card game, but some mechanics make this too random and less strategic as it could have been. There should be more team building and less random swapping and then the game would be really interesting. Great artwork and geek references though.

item.name: Sleeping Queens
item.comment: A light and cute looking take that style card game with a minimum of hand management and lots of luck. A fun game, especially for kids (make that girls) with gorgeous illustrations. Good filler.

item.name: Sleuth
item.comment: One of my Dad's collection games. A nice game which is oddly social and non-social at the same time. You have to talk with the other players, but other than that, everyone pretty much sees to his own hand of cards alone. Still, a nice and simple deduction game.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: The perfect mix of randomness and strategy/skill. Simple rules but very flexible and thus extremely tweakable and expendable, a thing I like about games. The idea of having different boards for different player numbers is a bit odd but works quite well. The theme is funny and quirky and although I do prefer high-fantasy settings, Smallworld's theme fits the concept far better.

item.name: Small World: Cursed!
item.comment: Good Expansion for the game, although it is a bit steep considerning the content. Any completist would want this but it does not change the game much.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
item.comment: Another good expansion which is again a bit too expensive considering the content. Could have done with one or two more skills and the priestesses are not that interesting. Any completist would want this.

item.name: Small World: Tales and Legends
item.comment:
The expansion makes the definitely more enjoyable and finally an expansion (the third one!) which actually alters some gameplay, i.e. adds something new to it, not just more of the same. Like the other expansions, the packaging etc. is a tad underwhelming and one asks himself how anything exciting can be hidden within that deck of cards. Well there is, lots of random events, cute artwork and lots of new variety injected into the game. However, I would have preferred some more madness and randomness. Many of the cards are very straightforward and only slight alterations, Woods score and extra point, mountains can not be conquered etc. While others really cause some mayhem (like adding a second skill to your races, cool). Of course you can adjust the game (rules included) to emphasis on the more critical events, but why not make the expansion have more impact in the first place. I would also have preferred a few new tokes with the events, but it looks like Smallworld is only the fosterchild of Days of Wonder (unlike Ticket to Ride). Still, for fans and friends of Smallworld, this is a must.
EDIT: The only way I can play small world and still enjoy it.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: A chaotic card game, similar to Small World in terms of combinable player powers (i.e. shuffle to types of creatures together and go for it), but features more direct conflict and lots (!) more exceptions to the relaitvely simple rules. All the possible combinations of races make for great replayability but it might take some time for players to learn the races' advantages by heart and play towards their respective strength. On the other hand, the thematic aspect of the game is a great laugh and I for one love the idea of Dinosaur-Ninjas facing off against Undead-Russians (riding bears). Not sure how balanced all the race combinations are and a lot depends on card draws, then again, the game I played felt very balanced.

item.name: Snorta!
item.comment: For a silly party game, this is incredibly tough because there is actually no luck involved, only skill, albeit no strategic skill but awareness and a quick reaction time.

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment: If you are used to the ingenious simplicity of Ave Caesar, all other racing games have to stand up to the test of the Roman chariot racing game. Snow Tails is one of the few racing games that I enjoyed. It takes a few turns to get your head around the rules but once things begin to slide, it is all in good fun. However, I am not sure how much long-term strategy there is to the game as you can only really see your next two or three hands but I suppose that is what you want in a racing game, more feverish thrill than dull planning ahead. The board and general artwork look amazing, a shame the sleighs look a bit dull. Good racing game, will probably go up in my estimation after more plays.

item.name: Solo
item.comment: A good alternative to Uno or Rage. Solo is way more fun due to the game mechanics which break up the classic flow of card gaming, switch hands, switch playing directions and so forth. A nice game to introduce traditional card gamers to more complex gaming. They will love it. I know I did.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment:
Apart from the superfrenzy created by the real-time aspect of the game, the core game is still a basic coopeative puzzler. I did enjoy it but was both underwhelmed by the strategic possibilites and the non-thematic experience and overwhelmed by the diffictulty of communicating with your fellow players. I have only played a basic (training) version of the game and maybe I will need to explore it more and play with right people as well, but for now, this is a mixed bag for me and I would rather play a similar game (puzzler like Ghost Stories or Space disaster like BSG) but indulge in what the game generates in atmosphere and tension instead of rushing though it like that.
EDIT: Played this with the 'right' group of people, finally, a few of my close friends and really enjoyed it this time. I think this is a great game if you have good group and are interested in playing though all the missions.

item.name: Space Crusade
item.comment: In the aftermath of my HeroQuest addiction, I bought many "Dungeon" crawler games a la Space Crusade. The game appealed to my friends more than hero quest, because of the gritty sci-fi theme. Although I do prefer HeroQuest, Space Crusade is a nice game and can be quite thrilling when you play it with the right people.

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment: What a treat for an Ameritrash-gamer. Amazing tiles and minaiture, plus exciting and thrilling scenarios that pit the crazy marines against the feverish genestealers coming from all corners. Played with the right people and atmosphere, this game would creep the shingles out of me. The rules are simple enough with a few exceptions and fiddly rules you need to remember but the flow of the game is great. The timed turn for the marines both prevents AP and makes the game more exciting. Love it, it is a shame it is so hard to track down.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment: Not keen on the W40K Universe in the first place. I found the game too fiddly and all the setting up throughout the game takes longer than the actual playing time. The game is deceiptively simple, despite all the different actions on the cards and comes down to two die rolls. Not my cup of tea.

item.name: Space Walk
item.comment: Quite an abstract game and I think it might be quite rewarding to become better and better (preferably with the same opponent) to really enjoy the ingeniuty of subtleties such as starting set-up and moving your ships around. Then again, at this point, it just feels a tad random and uninspired, due to the fact that the game mechanics itself are rather dull. The theme is non-existent (this is an abstract, no less) but the board and bits still look good so that is a plus and it might even attract the attention of young gamers and families due to its presentation.

item.name: Spectral Rails
item.comment: I am not sure if we played this right but I found this game a bit too chaotic and all-over-the-place. The theme is interesting but I did not like it. It is a train game after all and why not stick to the train theme and make it all goofy and crazy, unless you really make it a game that is considerably different from all other train games.

item.name: The Speicherstadt
item.comment: This game is more or less carried by one single, albeit clever mechanic. And what is wrong with making that one special mechanic the axis and focal point of the game ? I actually like Speicherstadt's minimalist and purist approach and apart from the odd 'fire' concept that might have been a leftover from a previously more sophisticated design, the game relies solely one a few nitty-gritty rules and mechanics. The theme is almost non-existent but the bits are nice, the money and the artwork on the cards. A solid variation of the bidding/collection genre.

item.name: Spion & Spion
item.comment: Played this a few times, because I used to be a fan of the comic strips. Never really understood the game and kept inventing my own rules as a young lad. Not a very good game from what I heard.

item.name: Star Borders: Humanity
item.comment: An interesting 2-player light-wargame. The core of the game is capturing planets, moving your ships around, combat and maybe repairing or replacing the odd ship. However, what makes the game interesting are the special power cards that grant you abilities that can make the whole game experience different. It might be the ability to beam ships around the board, blow ships up in suicide missions, repair ships for free etc. This makes for some great replayability, let alone the four scenarios that come with the game. I liked this game a lot.

item.name: Star Trek: Expeditions
item.comment: Played this only once and was both disappointed and slightly overwhelmed by all the number-crunching, doublechecking of skills and so forth. Maybe I am old school and I understand that this is an 'Expedition' game but a Star Trek game that is not set on the Enterprise ? That just feels wrong and not thematic at all. The production value of this game is good, although the pieces sacrifice usability for style and some of the numbers in the Clix-figures and ships are really hard to see. There is some thematic mambo-jambo on the cards but those are just placeholders and I have rarely seen a thematic game with less theme or story or flavour for that matter behind it. We did not care for it and why would you. The only thing that matters in this game is numbers and colours you have to match and then roll a few dice here and there (Knizia anyone?). If this would not have this great license, I think people would not enjoy it as much, I know I would not. Oddly enough, I found this to inelegantly designed and shallow at the same time. Not my cup of tea. Also, replayability is not very high.

item.name: Star Wars: Escape From The Death Star
item.comment: An interesting race against time kind of game (in this case, against the ever-looming presence of Lord Vader). You try feverishly to shake off the stormtroopers while making your way across the map towards the exit and Millenium Falcon (but not before switching off the tractor beam). A lot in this game comes down to die rolls and card draws, some limited decisions have to be made regarding risk taking ( on risk cards ), which character to send into the fray and when to use special ability boosting points from Droids and Obi Wan. It feels like a typical cooperative game of players vs. degrees of randomness. The theme makes this quite enjoyable, it is Star Wars after all, even though the components are not that good. I soloed this and will try it with other people to see whether the theme and excitment of replaying the Death Star Escape increases.

item.name: Stay Alive
item.comment: Nice game/toy for kids. I enjoyed this when I was younger and it is big fun, because despite being competitive, there is a lot of random element involved to make it free of grief.

item.name: Steam
item.comment: Only played the basic game with three players but enjoyed it more than Age of Steam, but only slightly. I think the game is neat but there is not enough luck involved for my taste and it is more or less a brain burning puzzle game and the eggheads will usually just solve the board and beat you to it. Also, towards the end (the last few rounds), the games becomes less about expansion than about repeatedly running the already efficient machine which I found a bit stalling. Still, neat game and I would play again.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Played this with my dad and was always thrilled when it came to the moment to turn the playing pieces around in order to uncover the unit type, whoah ! It is impressive how a game can rely on such a simple game mechanic to make it exciting. Yet it works and is a classic of streamlined wargaming.

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment: I enjoyed this game very much and only played the basic game. A super-involved, dynamic and tense 2-player duel. It is great how different the sides play (as compared to most other 2-player games) and with the random setup,the game is quite random in its setup (apart from card draws etc.). Am really impressed by the design, although the rulebook is terrible (and the million reference sheets available are not much of a help either). Apart from that, great game and a candidate for a 10 (depending on how the advanced game plays)

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: A great civilization variant with a handful of key mechanics which makes this stand out from the average bulk of civ games. The bidding for alliances bid is an amazing mechanic and really what this whole game is about. Of course, apart from the official alliances, there is no limited as to how many spoken agreement can be made and broken, lots of backstabbing and negotiation going on. I have played it only once but found that some players overreact whenever you become to vicious, despite the fact that the game and theme calls for being ruthless, so be careful who you play with, this is a sure-fire temper riser. The initial setup adds some randomness which makes this game way more re-playable than other civ games. It takes a while to learn all the available upgrades and such by heart but once you manage to, the game is actually very simple. The board and card artwork could do with an overhaul, both in style as well as usability but that is a minor issue. All in all, an above than average civ game which should be your holy grail if you are really into the subject matter. It is not my preferred theme and as I said, I am usually a nasty player and like to be vicious and cruel when playing games which call for it and found that many geeks cannot take it because to them, gaming is everything and they cannot lose. Great game. HX

item.name: Sumeria
item.comment: I did not enjoy Sumeria, the theme is awfully generic and the game is pretty much an abstract area control game with bizarre and frustrating rules for starting player which are almost random and can be very annoying and there the control over what is going on in the game is too limited with four players, because you can never really predict what other people will be doing. Too dry and too clunky for me.

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment: A neat little drafting game and uber-simplified 7 Wonders. Which makes a better filler than the latter. The theme is plastered on but works well. Some people claim there is luck involved, but all cards are known and which ones come back to you is solely determined by players' choices. I enjoyed it.

item.name: Sushizock im Gockelwok
item.comment:
A very simple and slick Knizia game and maybe one of his best. The game plays and feels nice, solid pieces and nice dice. There is enough dice rolling to make it random and enough push-your-luck elements to make it tactical. Great travel game.
EDIT: Played it again and found it a bit less exciting due to the limited player interaction. Maybe it was just bad luck but the chopsticks seem to come up at such a rare rate that the game is dominated by doing your own thing instead of caring what the others do too much

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment: A games that only makes sense once you start playing it and even then probably not earlier halfway through. The game is essentially a card-game with some bluffing and hand management beefed up with some placement and tile collection (yes, it is a Knizia). However, in this case, I found that there is less skill involved than in many other Knizia games and a lot comes down to luck in this game (That is, if you consider random actions by other players luck). It might be something you are used to when playing a Knizia game, but this one is particularly ugly and the 'theme' or visuals add nothing to the enjoyment of the game, let alone making easier to play. The cards are really confusing. Why show two elephants on the card when it is worth one ? I thought this was okay. A typical Knizia that is missing that certain something that most of his other games have.

item.name: Take 5!
item.comment: Definitely a step-up from 6 nimmt ! This game is a bit more complex and the fact that it comes with plus AND minus points should be enough to tell you that this is not as easy a game to learn and play as 6 nimmt. However, that probably only applies if you are playing with 2 or 3 players, because just like 6 nimmt!, if you player with too many players, all derails into chaos (not a bad thing necessarily) but it might make the game a completely different experience than it should be. For a 'card game' if found this too complex and puzzle-like.

item.name: Tales & Games: The Hare & the Tortoise
item.comment: A neat racing game that reminds me of Heimlich & Co. The artwork and pieces are really cute. Even though the tile-based gameboard is a tad fiddly. Then again, that makes it easier to fit it in the "Book" box. There is not a lot of strategy here when it comes to the hidden bets, due to the fact that it becomes very obvious early on, which player chose which animal to support / bet on. I wish there would be a bit more depth there. On the other hand, that might have made the game less family friendy.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: Most definitely an unusual concept for a 'game'. Pretty much a collective storytelling experience which makes an effort to maintain the illusion of the presence of decision making. An interesting game, a tad too random and unfathomable maybe. I am not sure how it would hold up after multiple plays but that remains to be seen.

item.name: Talisman
item.comment: I love randomness so this game is lots of fun, it feels more like a weird racing game than a crawler but the competitive aspect makes it fun, fighting and chasing other players. The most annoying thing is the movement mechanic and the board which can be quite hard to read depending on where you are sitting. The characters are very diverse (and many) which is amazing, sadly the diversity does not carry over to the enemies and items you can find, alas, I would have prefered more items to cause the game to go topsyturvy but I guess that would have thrown too many people of. Still, with the right people that can have a laugh, this game is fun.

item.name: The Talisman Dungeon
item.comment: Not to keen on that one. The dungeon adds another board that is way too similar to the original to be that appealing. Going into the dungeon is not that exciting or good of an option.

item.name: Talisman: The Adventure
item.comment: More of the same is always good, new chars, spells and adventure cards. The idea of having different endings is the best thing about this expansion and adds to the chaotic randomness of Talisman. The optional rules are not that exciting and not very thought through in my opinion.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: Right off the bat I can say that I adore the bits & pieces of this game, nice artwork, sturdy tiles and cute little buildings, great. The game itself is a Carcassonne plus 3D plus Puzzle variant which is more intricate than it looks. I have played it once and was overwhelmed at first and intrigued later. I reckon that the game becomes more cutthroat and interactive the more experienced the players become and start minding not only their own business. A good game with a slightly confusing final scoring system but other than that, thumbs up, this is subject to increase in rating once I get my head around it.

item.name: Tammany Hall
item.comment: One of the few and rare occasions when I can truly say that a heavy Euro game with cubes still feels right on theme. The map looks gorgeous and the flow of the game is very tight and interactive. It would have been nice if there would be a stronger meta-game promoted by the game (mechanics) but this is nonetheless a very unique game.

item.name: Therapy
item.comment: Me and my mates found this game very rewarding in our teenage years, in order to get to know each other and play around with ideas of self-concept and identities. The game can be tweaked to be more social than a trivia game. It is a nice game to play with non-gamers and couples.

item.name: Three-Dragon Ante
item.comment: A good card game which keeps a nice flow going which might be due to the fact that it feels very much like a traditional card-game which clearly seems to have been the intention. Simple rules, flexibility in the decks and high re-playability as well as multiple ways of going about winning make this a very slick and enjoyable game. HX

item.name: Thrill
item.comment: More or less a dexterity than a board game. The production value is not very good, the plastic pieces tend not to work right all the time. The novelty pretty much wears off very soon. The game is probably tailored towards very young children.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: A very light 'train' game with an interesting take on victory points. There is a solid mixture of luck and strategy in here. The game plays much quicker than most similar games. I like the artwork on the board although it makes it hard to see towns and routes for people who are visually impaired.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: Played this again and quiet enjoyed it. I think it is important or at least more enjoyable if you play it with people of the same skill level.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Not a bad game by any account, but considering this is one of the most popular gateway games I did expect more of an intriguingly designed game with some irresistible finesse, a la Settlers of Catan or Carcassonne, two games which are simple, yet ingenious. But Ticket to Ride is more or less nothing but the collection of coloured cards and playing this cards as soon as you accumulated the target number (the higher the better). Throw in the whole kerfuffle about train routes and the ability to 'block' other players and you have yourself a boardgame. It works alright and is not bad but I feel that the game is not more than the sum of its parts and it does not click with me.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: The theme is rather dry, like with most Knizia games. It is more or less a competitive puzzle game which I do not really like, not enough luck involved and the programmers always win. Also, I think the flow of the game is too heavy and a few less rules would have done the game good, the weight is just too heavy for that kind of game, and I would either play something more elegant or something more themed.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: Lovely marriage of theme vs. mechanics, a tad AP prone, especally towards the end but a nice game with just enough randomness (tile draw) to make it a family-compatible game, yet strategy and experience usually wins.

item.name: Time's Up!
item.comment: It might take a while to get through one round, but it is still lots and lots of fun

item.name: Time's Up! Title Recall!
item.comment: Finally played this game and it was as good as I expected. It does not matter that much whether you know all the titles, in fact, seeing someone describing something or miming a title he never heard about can be a tearjerker, because people only have the words in the title to work with. It was surprise how the scaling down of available options in portraying the clue works, because all players see all clues eventually and you can figure the answer out just because you know which cards are in play. Fantastic party game, A must-have.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment: This feels like Yahtzee meets Dominion, way too fiddly for me. Figuring out what all the cards do and you can get from your rolled dice is just work, no fun. Nice artwork though.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
item.comment: I think Last Night on Earth and Invasion from Outer Space are good games and their simple and fast playing style suits them well. Lots of dice rolling, movement (grid system), lots of card-plays, light skirmish gaming. A Touch of Evil however walks down a different path and it does not work in my opinion. The game is essentially a very thematic (ameritrash) game but there is not enough theme in it too make it work. If you compare this to Arkham Horror, it feels like going to a country fair when you could go to Disneyland. The rules are fiddly and inelegant, sometimes nothing exciting happens and there is no atmosphere at all. Disappointing.

item.name: Trans Europa
item.comment: Pretty much the same game as Transamerica. I do enjoy this game also I would recommend playing it with the Vexation extension as it might be seriously underwhelming otherwise. The European map is a wee more chaotic and harder in my opinion, although some argue about this point. The basic premise is a simple as it gets and the game is after all very luck based if you have evenly skiller players which might put more serious gamers off. Not much of a theme either. I do enjoy it however, if only for the short time it takes to play and pick up.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: Another train game. I found it quite fun for a filler, although it is way too solvable, especially for experienced players, there is always a "best" way to go , you only have to know which, but once you do, the game plays very linear and stagnant. The theme is very thin and I have seen train games which encompass the homely "feeling" of trains and tracks way better. A few more random elements, turn options and abilities to influence other players' moves and decision.

item.name: Traumfabrik
item.comment: Played the Traumfabrik version and was surprised how simple this game actually is. At its heart, it is nothing but a tile collecting game with an auction mechanic. Yet, theme theme makes it more exciting than your average farmer fare. I still think the game could have done with a bit more interaction but I suppose with more plays, the players will start looking out for each others' productions to be to a higher extent, hoping to grab the film awards first and ending up with the best film in the respective genres. Definitely a little gem when played with film fans.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: 20th Anniversary Edition
item.comment: This is not a game, it is a torture device. Running around the board is incredibly tedious, especially with "roll again" fields, some turns are just that, roll and roll and roll the dice, so boring it makes me dizzy. The question are just trivia, unimaginative and boring, either you not or you don't, where is the game in that ? HX

item.name: Troyes
item.comment: I can honestly see where this game is coming from. The first dice allocation game I played was Kingsburg which is probably the most simple of the bunch. I played Alien Frontiers and did not like the theme and found it a tad more complex than the former. Troyes however is the behemoth of the trio and takes the dice allocation mechanic and beefs it up with lots of stuff, rules and tweaks. If you are a fan of the genre, that is, someone who looks for more of the same in a heavier context, Troyes is the go-to game for you. However, I still prefer Kingsburg because the game keeps it simple, focuses more on interaction instead of calculations and brainburning. Troyes takes it one level to far (for me) but I can see why some people might really like it. I am not keen on the fact that you get an advantage by learning the cards by heart either, I do not like that, I want my games to be decided by skill, not by sheer investment of time into preparing for it beforehand.

item.name: Tulipmania 1637
item.comment: Another example that a good critic does not make a good author. Tulipmania is incredibly boring and brainy, pretty much like playing pong on a calculator. There is number crunching without the excitment of a stock market and is incredibly easy to "solve" the game and use the right tactics as they options to influence/sabotage the other players are way too limited to make a game in which the players are so interdependant interesting. Take a horrible theme and terrible artwork and you have yourself a crappy game.

item.name: TurfMaster
item.comment: A great way to describe this (and I am paraphrasing John B. here) is that this actually feels like a racing game. No betting, waging, secret movement or shooting rockets at others but speed, anticipation of others' movements, risk and a bit of luck/momentum. The artwork is not that good and the game lacks the gritty atmosphere of Win,Place and Show but this is a very good racing game. Definitely best with the fences.

item.name: Tutankhamen
item.comment: Yikes ! One play left me more than unsatisfied, this must be one of the Doctor's 350 bad games. This is so random and pointless that is almost hurts and we almost laughed while playing, that is who weird it was. Maybe it plays better with 5 or 6 players and I will try it once more just too see whether it changes anything, but this will not turn into a great game anytime soon.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment: I was a bit underwhelmed by this. This game is not bad by any account but I cannot see more than the sum of its parts. Neat and complicated mechanics but stale and rather static gameplay. I was never really excited while playing this but felt like carefully executing a fine plan without the spirit of adventure and chaos you would expect from a game of interstellar conflict and colonization. I can see why people like this but I need more chaos, randomness and surprise in my games.

item.name: Ubongo Mini
item.comment: This is probably as dull and unimaginative as it gets. Just put forms into templates and make sure they fit and be faster than your opponent. It's like being a specimen in a monkey lab, but without the bananas and reproduction sessions (i.e. NO FUN). Steer clear of this one

item.name: Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition
item.comment: I was worried that now that I have played newer traitor games such as The Resistance or BSG, I would not enjoy Werewolf at all, but I was wrong. The game is very interesting (with a large enough group at least) and while you can most definitely sense the familiarity with the aforementioned games, it warrants its own existence within the world of gaming. It feels much more open, social and narrative compared to The Resistance and this edition of all things adds a lot to it with all the different character cards etc. I am not a big fan of a manual that gives you two dozens of variant without at least suggesting where to start or which one works best (in the opinion of the designer). With the right group, this can be a hoot !

item.name: UNO
item.comment: As simple as it gets, enjoyable nonetheless. Good family game, that can be picked up quickly by everyone and relies on random draws enough to balance out player power.

item.name: War of the Ring (first edition)
item.comment: Played this beast for the first time and it did not disappoint, sure, getting your head around the rules is a legendary feat but worth your while and the the rules are at least coherent and not badly written (like so many other games). It seems there are much more possible strategies than meet the eye and I quite like the idea of tactics being shaped through the random card draws (although I think there should have been a few more). A deep and engaging game. I love the theme (Tolkien !) and I think nothing needs to be said about the artwork and miniature etc. While not the most efficient (the map can be confusing and the figures look alike in parts), they are gorgeous. Brilliant Game. One of my favourites

item.name: Warrior Knights
item.comment:
Was keen to play this because it sounds good on paper but there first play was really tough and did not click (so far). The rules are very unclear and vague in parts which makes it more of a grind to learn and play than necessary. The game end trigger is a bit rubbish. The 10 influence points per player is too short but playing with the Might is Right variant will just cause the game to go on forever, where was the playtesting ? Maybe it is just because we played the game with three players but there had not been a single PVP confrontation in the whole game, bit dull. Everyone just went for the weak neutrals and hoped for the best.
I still think there is potential here but I wish I would not be so hard to find.

item.name: Waterworks
item.comment: Played this as a kid. Enjoyed it for a short while but the novelty quickly wore off.

item.name: Wealth of Nations
item.comment: A good game of world economy. Mechanics are simple, yet make a complex and interesting game nonetheless. The playing pieces are very nice and add greatly to the fun, as compared to drier and more abstract economy games such as Monopoloy.

item.name: Web of Gold
item.comment: Played this extensively in solitaire when I was a young lad. Enjoyed it very much. Fleeing from the spiders. Pretty much a dungeon crawler / adventure game. Great fun with kids and non-gamers or girls. Underrated.

item.name: Werewolf
item.comment: Always great fun with the right (number of) people and the right roles. Need to track a down a proper copy of this one!

item.name: Wheel of Fortune
item.comment: Mediocre game for the odd family game. Nothing spectacular

item.name: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire
item.comment: The boardgame of WWTOBAM lacks all the intensity of the TV show (if you can call it intense at all that is) and players ask each other question after question after question and if you get it wrong your out. So, where is the game in that ? Oh right, this is no game at all. It is just a novelty merchandise product. Don't buy.

item.name: Wiggling Cow
item.comment: Another good and simple dexterity game from HABA. Good stuff, like Mikado for kids.

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: Pretty much a very sugarcoated hidden identity movement game with a rich and pleasant theme woven around it. The game is very simply and lots of it depends on dice. I am not sure whether it actually plays better with less players because I found the fact that all horses had bets on them kind of weakened the idea of bluffing in the first place as all the horses eventually moved anyway. Still, the theme is great and the game can really animated a crowd.

item.name: Wit's End
item.comment: I like games which depart from the common trivia style by prompting players to think different and be more creative in your cognitive approach. Yet, Wit's end relies on players intelligence and knowledge and it becomes very unbalanced very quickly. I have played this a few times and I noticed players becoming very frustrated when they noticed that they had no chance to win. Not a very fun and social game.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment:
Played it only once in a pub and we got the rules wrong so I cannot pass judgment on it yet. I am sure it is more exciting when played with teams. So far, I found it a bit underwhelming and dull.
Edit: Played it again and it is far from being the super-outrageous partygame, that is, if you do not play in teams. I can see how this would be amazing in teams, but it will be hard to find 12 to 14 people. Still a great game, but I wish I had known that the experience is only half-baked when playing without teams.

item.name: Wits & Wagers Family
item.comment: Comments pending.

item.name: Wizard
item.comment: This game is good fun and behind the pretty straight-forward trick taking game lies a nice underbelly of risk-assessment and push-your-luck mechanics. It helped that I played this with very nice people !

item.name: The Wonderful World of Disney Trivia Game
item.comment: Same old, same old. Trivia games are rarely innovative and interesting. Race around the board and answer all sorts of Disney question. Good for kids and Disney fans, but are purely factual game, which is something I loathe. If you do not know it, tough luck, no cleverness or wit will help you out. HX

item.name: Word on the Street
item.comment:
An interesting wordgame that might get even more interesting with more players (i.e. Team Play). We played it back to back as a 2-Player game and it had the tendency to drag on towards the end with only a handful letters going back and forth. The basic idea is very cool but I found that some if not most of the cards are a bit bland and not very creative. For example, instead of making one side easy and hard ( Actually, I found the easy ones much harder than the hard ones ), they could have made one side regular questions (A mammal) and the other side crazy/fun questions ( A stupid Halloween costume etc.).
Still, a neat family / word game

item.name: World Without End
item.comment: A fabulous mixture of classic Euro mechanics and randomness but still perfectly balanced because all players have the same obstacles to overcome. Good playing time and amazing artwork. One of my favourite Euros so far.

item.name: WWF Wrestling Challenge
item.comment: Used to be a WWF fan as a kid and had to buy this game. I was surprised by the depth of mechanics of it and quite enjoyed for a while.

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: The game does sound way more complicated that it. It is pretty much a rummy-style game with players trying to collect the most cards of a specific outlaw as possible in order to reek in the biggest awards. The game is spiced up with action cards than can both hurt other players and benefit yourself but can also go wrong. The theme is nice and better than just using generic suits etc. Still, the game can be a bit daunting at times, but it becomes clear once you start playing a few hands. Might be a tad too long for what it is but I suppose you can't just lower the winning VP threshold. There might be a lot of luck involved in the card drawing too, which I don't mind but hardcore card game purist might find that not very amusing.

item.name: Yahtzee
item.comment: For some reason, my brother loves this game. He played it for ages when he was in hospital. I was never a fan of dicepool games and still not enjoy it that much.

item.name: Yin Yang
item.comment: As light as it gets, a simple Knizia cardgame. Not super elegant but effective. The last few cards are almost random and the game reminds of 6 Nimmt ( Category 5) and how you the best laid plans can end up in total chaos in the last turn which makes the game more luck-based and more of a filler than anything else.

item.name: You Robot
item.comment:
A great party game that gets people involved. The fact alone that you don't play it one a table but in a room, walking around and doing silly things terrifies some people but many others do enjoy it. If you are not that fussy about the rules, than you will have a great time with 4 to 6 people, or maybe more ? Good stuff.
EDIT: Pretty much an exercise in silliness. The vague rules however can make the game a bit frustrating. What exactly are you allowed to do, mime, say, gesture, say with your expression etc. and if you are trying to play this game to win, it is a bit hard without having a few referees around as there is no way of telling if people stuck to the rules (whatever they may be). A silly and fun past time but not a game in the true sense of the word.

item.name: You're Bluffing!
item.comment:
A very simple yet elegant auction / bluffing game about collecting sets. However the crux lies in the fact that you offer a number of cards (yet the actual value remains hidden). Lovely little gem.
EDIT: Burned out a bit on it after only half a dozen plays. Still a nice game but there are a few 'tricks' and 'loopholes' which ca quickly annihilate new players and I think those mechanics could have used some more playtesting and tweaking. Also,the game plays very similar each time.
EDIT2: Played this again after quite some time and somehow it always plays the same and follows the same pattern. Unfortunately I feel there are quiet a few loopholes of strategy in the game that can be exploited by experienced players.

item.name: Zendo
item.comment: I can see how this game seems overwhelming at first sight and more or less like a super brainburner or a tediou excercise in trial and error like Mastermind (to which this game is wrongly compared), but if played with a lively bunch which do not mind some collective vocal pondering this becomes a fantastic experience and requires some thinking outside of the box (literally). Simple yet very effective, Zendo is a great game.

item.name: Zing!
item.comment: Great card game in the tradition of Wizard. Make sure to win the right number and colour of tricks to avoid points. All this plus a saboteur whose goal it is to screw everyone else up ! Pretty neat card game.

item.name: Zombie Dice
item.comment: Superlight Push Your Luck Filler with a neat "theme". I say theme but it's really just the artwork on the casing and coloured dice. It is barely playable with my house rules but otherwise just an act of randomness. Might be fun with kids or non-gamers as a filler.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Solid Agricola-Super Light with each player caring and growing its own Zoo on a seperate board. The interaction comes with choosing which animals (truck) to take, just like in Coloretto and buying animals from other players' barns, even though this does not happen enough and should be cheaper in my opinion, in order to promote player interaction a tad more. Still, cute theme and artwork.
